         <td><a href="/wiki/.dk" title=".dk">.dk</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a></td>
       </tr></table>
<p><b>Denmark</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-da (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-da</a>), officially the <b>Kingdom of Denmark</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-da (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-da</a>), is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sovereign_state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sovereign state (page does not exist)">sovereign state</a> in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">Northern Europe</a>, located south-west of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>, south of <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, and bordered to the south by <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>. The Kingdom has two autonomous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Constituent_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Constituent country (page does not exist)">constituent countries</a> in the north <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>. At <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-mundi_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mundi-8">[8]</a></sup> and a population of around 5.6 million inhabitants, Denmark consists of a peninsula, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jutland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jutland (page does not exist)">Jutland</a>, and the Danish archipelago of <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Denmark" title="List of islands of Denmark">407 islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> of which around 70 are inhabited, are characterised by flat, arable land and sandy coasts with little elevation and a <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate</a> climate. The national language, <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>, is <a href="/wiki/North_Germanic_languages" title="North Germanic languages">closely related</a> to and <a href="/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility" title="Mutual intelligibility">mutually intelligible</a> with <a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">Swedish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norwegian_language" title="Norwegian language">Norwegian</a>.
</p><p>The Kingdom of Denmark is a unitary <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> with <a href="/wiki/Margrethe_II_of_Denmark" title="Margrethe II of Denmark">Margrethe II</a> as <a href="/wiki/Queen_regnant" title="Queen regnant">queen regnant</a>, organised in a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary</a> democracy. Ending <a href="/wiki/Absolute_monarchy" title="Absolute monarchy">absolute monarchy</a> introduced in 1660, the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Denmark" title="Constitution of Denmark">Constitution of Denmark</a> was signed on 5 June 1849, only to be rewritten four times; the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Denmark#Changes" title="Constitution of Denmark">latest revision</a> in 1953. The government resides in the capital of <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a>. Denmark<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> exercises <a href="/wiki/Hegemony" title="Hegemony">hegemonic</a> influence in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Realm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Realm (page does not exist)">Danish Realm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolving</a> political powers to handle internal affairs to the Faroe Islands and Greenland. Denmark became a member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 1973, maintaining <a href="/w/index.php?title=Opt-outs_in_the_European_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Opt-outs in the European Union (page does not exist)">four opt-outs</a> from European Union policies, as outlined in the 1992 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edinburgh_Agreement_(1992)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edinburgh Agreement (1992) (page does not exist)">Edinburgh Agreement</a>. Both the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands_and_the_European_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands and the European Union (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenland_and_the_EU&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenland and the EU (page does not exist)">Greenland</a> remain outside the Union.
</p><p>Home of the <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Vikings</a>, the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Denmark" title="History of Denmark">unified kingdom of Denmark</a> emerged in the 8th century as a proficient seafaring nation in the struggle for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominium_maris_baltici&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominium maris baltici (page does not exist)">control of the Baltic Sea</a>. The establishment of the personal <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_Union" title="Kalmar Union">Kalmar Union</a> under Danish rule in 1397 ended with Swedish secession in 1523; one year later, Denmark entered <a href="/w/index.php?title=Denmark-Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Denmark-Norway (page does not exist)">union with Norway</a> until its dissolution in 1814. Several <a href="/wiki/Cession" title="Cession">cessions</a> of Danish territory that had begun in the 17th century caused a surge of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Denmark#The_19th_century" title="History of Denmark">nationalist movements</a> that gained momentum in the 1830s and concluded with a defeat in the 1864 <a href="/wiki/Second_Schleswig_War" title="Second Schleswig War">Second Schleswig War</a>. Denmark remained neutral during <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_invasion_of_Denmark_(1940)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German invasion of Denmark (1940) (page does not exist)">German invasion</a> in April 1940 saw brief military skirmishes while the <a href="/wiki/Danish_resistance_movement" title="Danish resistance movement">Danish resistance movement</a> was active from 1943 until the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Occupation of Denmark (page does not exist)">German surrender</a> in May 1945.  Denmark abandoned its traditional neutrality by joining <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 1949. An industrialized exporter of agricultural produce in the second half of the 19th century, Denmark introduced <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kanslergade_Agreement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kanslergade Agreement (page does not exist)">social and labour-market reforms</a> in the early decades of the 20th century, making the basis for the present <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nordic_model&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nordic model (page does not exist)">welfare state</a> with a highly developed <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed market</a> economy. The <a href="/wiki/Danish_krone" title="Danish krone">Danish krone</a> has been pegged to the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> since 1 January 1999.
</p><p>Denmark is frequently ranked as the happiest country in the world in cross-national studies of <a href="/wiki/Happiness" title="Happiness">happiness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Taylor_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taylor-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Levy_article_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levy_article-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BruceStokes_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BruceStokes-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sauter_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sauter-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Earth_Institute_2013_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Earth_Institute_2013-14">[14]</a></sup> Denmark ranks as having the world's highest <a href="/wiki/Social_mobility" title="Social mobility">social mobility</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> a high  level of <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" title="List of countries by income equality">income equality</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> has one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">highest per capita income</a>, and has one of the worlds highest personal income tax rates.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> For 2013, Denmark is listed 15th on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> and 9th on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_inequality-adjusted_HDI&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by inequality-adjusted HDI (page does not exist)">inequality-adjusted HDI</a>. Denmark ranks highly positive on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corruption_Perceptions_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corruption Perceptions Index (page does not exist)">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legatum_Prosperity_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legatum Prosperity Index (page does not exist)">Legatum Prosperity Index</a>, and as a full democracy on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democracy_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democracy Index (page does not exist)">Democracy Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Denmark is among the founding members of the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Council" title="Nordic Council">Nordic Council</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (page does not exist)">OECD</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>. There are three Danish heritage sites inscribed on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Northern_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Northern Europe (page does not exist)">World Heritage list in Northern Europe</a>. Greenland, which is part of the Kingdom of Denmark, has one of the highest suicide rates in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
