<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The etymology of the word Denmark, and especially the relationship between Danes and Denmark and the unifying of Denmark as a single kingdom, is a subject which attracts debate.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> This is centred primarily on the prefix <i>"Dan"</i> and whether it refers to the <a href="/wiki/Danes_(Germanic_tribe)" title="Danes (Germanic tribe)">Dani</a> or a historical person <a href="/wiki/Dan_(king)" title="Dan (king)">Dan</a> and the exact meaning of the -<i>"mark"</i> ending. The issue is further complicated by a number of references to various Dani people in Scandinavia or other places in Europe in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Roman</a> accounts (like <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordanes" title="Jordanes">Jordanes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gregory_of_Tours" title="Gregory of Tours">Gregory of Tours</a>), as well as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediaeval_literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediaeval literature (page does not exist)">mediaeval literature</a> (like <a href="/wiki/Adam_of_Bremen" title="Adam of Bremen">Adam of Bremen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beowulf" title="Beowulf">Beowulf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Widsith" title="Widsith">Widsith</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Poetic_Edda" title="Poetic Edda">Poetic Edda</a>).
</p><p>Most handbooks derive<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> the first part of the word, and the name of the people, from a word meaning "flat land", related to German <i>Tenne</i> "threshing floor", English <i>den</i> "cave", <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> <i>dhánuṣ-</i> (धनुस्; "desert"). The <i>-mark</i> is believed to mean woodland or borderland (see <a href="/wiki/March_(territory)" title="March (territory)">marches</a>), with probable references to the border forests in south <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Schleswig" title="Duchy of Schleswig">Schleswig</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first recorded use of the word <i>Danmark</i> within Denmark itself is found on the two <a href="/wiki/Jelling_stones" title="Jelling stones">Jelling stones</a>, which are <a href="/wiki/Runestone" title="Runestone">runestones</a> believed to have been erected by <a href="/wiki/Gorm_the_Old" title="Gorm the Old">Gorm the Old</a> (c. 955) and <a href="/wiki/Harald_Bluetooth" title="Harald Bluetooth">Harald Bluetooth</a> (c. 965). The larger stone of the two is popularly cited as Denmark's baptismal certificate (<i>dåbsattest</i>), though both use the word "Denmark", in the form of <a href="/wiki/Accusative_case" title="Accusative case">accusative</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Runic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Runic (page does not exist)">Template:Runic</a> "tanmaurk" (<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[danmɒrk]</span>) on the large stone, and <a href="/wiki/Genitive_case" title="Genitive case">genitive</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Runic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Runic (page does not exist)">Template:Runic</a> "tanmarkar" (pronounced <span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[danmarkaɽ]</span>) on the small stone.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> The inhabitants of Denmark are there called "tani" (<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">[danɪ]</span>), or "Danes", in the accusative.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Trundholm.jpg" title="File:Trundholm.jpg">File:Trundholm.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The gilded side of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trundholm_sun_chariot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trundholm sun chariot (page does not exist)">Trundholm sun chariot</a> dating from the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Bronze_Age" title="Nordic Bronze Age">Nordic Bronze Age</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The earliest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Archaeology_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Archaeology of Denmark (page does not exist)">archaeological findings in Denmark</a> date back to the <a href="/wiki/Eemian" title="Eemian">Eem interglacial period</a> from 130,000–110,000 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> Denmark has been inhabited since around 12,500 BC and agriculture has been evident since 3900 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-foreign_ministry_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foreign_ministry-31">[31]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Bronze_Age" title="Nordic Bronze Age">Nordic Bronze Age</a> (1800–600 BC) in Denmark was marked by <a href="/wiki/Tumulus" title="Tumulus">burial mounds</a>, which left an abundance of findings including <a href="/wiki/Lur" title="Lur">lurs</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trundholm_sun_chariot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trundholm sun chariot (page does not exist)">Sun Chariot</a>.
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Roman_Iron_Age" title="Pre-Roman Iron Age">Pre-Roman Iron Age</a> (500 BC&#160;– AD 1), native groups began migrating south, although<sup id="cite_ref-foreign_ministry_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foreign_ministry-31">[31]</a></sup> the first Danish people came to the country between the Pre-Roman and the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_Iron_Age" title="Germanic Iron Age">Germanic Iron Age</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Iron_Age" title="Roman Iron Age">Roman Iron Age</a> (AD 1–400). The <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Roman provinces</a> maintained <a href="/wiki/Trade_route" title="Trade route">trade routes</a> and relations with native tribes in Denmark, and <a href="/wiki/Roman_currency" title="Roman currency">Roman coins</a> have been found in Denmark. Evidence of strong Celtic cultural influence dates from this period in Denmark and much of North-West Europe and is among other things reflected in the finding of the <a href="/wiki/Gundestrup_cauldron" title="Gundestrup cauldron">Gundestrup cauldron</a>.
</p><p>Historians believe that before the arrival of the precursors to the Danes, who came from the east <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Denmark" title="List of islands of Denmark">Danish islands</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Zealand_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zealand (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Zealand</a>) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scania (page does not exist)">Skåne</a> and spoke an early form of <a href="/wiki/North_Germanic_languages" title="North Germanic languages">North Germanic</a>, most of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jutland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jutland (page does not exist)">Jutland</a> and the nearest islands were settled by <a href="/wiki/Jutes" title="Jutes">Jutes</a>. They were later invited to Great Britain as mercenaries by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brythonic_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brythonic languages (page does not exist)">Brythonic</a> King <a href="/wiki/Vortigern" title="Vortigern">Vortigern</a> and were granted the south-eastern territories of <a href="/wiki/Kent" title="Kent">Kent</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Wight" title="Isle of Wight">Isle of Wight</a> among other areas, where they settled. They were later absorbed or <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnically cleansed</a> by the invading <a href="/wiki/Angles" title="Angles">Angles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saxons" title="Saxons">Saxons</a>, who formed the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxons" title="Anglo-Saxons">Anglo-Saxons</a>. The remaining population in Jutland assimilated in with the <a href="/wiki/Danes_(Germanic_tribe)" title="Danes (Germanic tribe)">Danes</a>.
</p><p>A short note about the <i>Dani</i> in "<a href="/wiki/Getica" title="Getica">Getica</a>" by the historian <a href="/wiki/Jordanes" title="Jordanes">Jordanes</a> is believed by some<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Who&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Who (page does not exist)">Template:Who</a> to be an early mention of the Danes, one of the <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">ethnic groups</a> from whom modern <a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danes</a> are descended.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Danevirke" title="Danevirke">Danevirke</a> defence structures were built in phases from the 3rd century forward and the sheer size of the construction efforts in AD 737 are attributed to the emergence of a Danish king.<sup id="cite_ref-danevirke_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-danevirke-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-danevirke_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-danevirke-35">[35]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Younger_Futhark" title="Younger Futhark">new runic alphabet</a> was first used around the same time and <a href="/wiki/Ribe" title="Ribe">Ribe</a>, the oldest town of Denmark, was founded about AD 700.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Viking_and_Middle_Ages">Viking and Middle Ages</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ladbyskibet.jpg" title="File:Ladbyskibet.jpg">File:Ladbyskibet.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ladby_ship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ladby ship (page does not exist)">Ladby ship</a>, the largest ship burial found in Denmark</div></div></div>
<p>From the 8th to the 10th century, the <a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danes</a>, which included <a href="/wiki/Norwegians" title="Norwegians">Norwegians</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swedes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swedes (page does not exist)">Swedes</a>, were known as <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Vikings</a>. They colonised, raided, and traded in all parts of Europe. Viking explorers first discovered <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> by accident in the 9th century, on the way towards the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a> and eventually came across "<a href="/wiki/Vinland" title="Vinland">Vinland</a>" (Land of wine), also known today as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Newfoundland (island) (page does not exist)">Newfoundland</a>, a province in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a>. The Danish Vikings were most active in the <a href="/wiki/British_Isles" title="British Isles">British Isles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>. They conquered and settled parts of England (known as the <a href="/wiki/Danelaw" title="Danelaw">Danelaw</a>) under King <a href="/wiki/Sweyn_Forkbeard" title="Sweyn Forkbeard">Sweyn Forkbeard</a> in 1013, <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a>, and France where they founded <a href="/wiki/Normandy" title="Normandy">Normandy</a>. More <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxons" title="Anglo-Saxons">Anglo-Saxon</a> <a href="/wiki/Pence" title="Pence" class="mw-redirect">pence</a> of this period have been found in Denmark than in England.<sup id="cite_ref-Lund_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lund-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>As attested by the <a href="/wiki/Jelling_stones" title="Jelling stones">Jelling stones</a>, the Danes were united and <a href="/wiki/Christianised" title="Christianised" class="mw-redirect">Christianised</a> about 965 by <a href="/wiki/Harald_Bluetooth" title="Harald Bluetooth">Harald Bluetooth</a>. It is believed that Denmark became Christian for political reasons so as not to get invaded by the rising <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Christian power</a> in Europe, <a href="/wiki/Germania" title="Germania">Germania</a>, which was an important trading area for the Danes. In that case Harald built six <a href="/wiki/Fortresses" title="Fortresses" class="mw-redirect">fortresses</a> around Denmark called <a href="/wiki/Viking_ring_fortress" title="Viking ring fortress">Trelleborg</a> and built a further <a href="/wiki/Danevirke" title="Danevirke">Danevirke</a>. In the early 11th century, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canute_the_Great&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canute the Great (page does not exist)">Canute the Great</a> won and united Denmark, England, and Norway for almost 30 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Lund_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lund-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout the <a href="/wiki/High_Middle_Ages" title="High Middle Ages">High</a> and <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">Late Middle Ages</a>, Denmark also included <a href="/wiki/Sk%C3%A5neland" title="Skåneland">Skåneland</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sk%C3%A5ne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skåne (page does not exist)">Skåne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Halland" title="Halland">Halland</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blekinge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blekinge (page does not exist)">Blekinge</a>) and Danish kings ruled <a href="/wiki/Danish_Estonia" title="Danish Estonia">Danish Estonia</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Duchy" title="Duchy">duchies</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schleswig&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schleswig (page does not exist)">Schleswig</a> and <a href="/wiki/Holstein" title="Holstein">Holstein</a>. Most of the latter two now form the state of <a href="/wiki/Schleswig-Holstein" title="Schleswig-Holstein">Schleswig-Holstein</a> in northern Germany.
</p><p>In 1397, Denmark entered into a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> with <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden-Finland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden-Finland (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>, united under Queen <a href="/wiki/Margaret_I_of_Denmark" title="Margaret I of Denmark">Margaret I</a>. The three countries were to be treated as equals in the union. However, even from the start Margaret may not have been so idealistic—treating Denmark as the clear "senior" partner of the union.<sup id="cite_ref-Lauring_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lauring-37">[37]</a></sup> Thus, much of the next 125 years of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Scandinavia" title="History of Scandinavia">Scandinavian history</a> revolves around this union, with Sweden breaking off and being re-conquered repeatedly. The issue was for practical purposes resolved on 17 June 1523, as <a href="/wiki/List_of_Swedish_monarchs" title="List of Swedish monarchs">Swedish King</a> <a href="/wiki/Gustav_I_of_Sweden" title="Gustav I of Sweden">Gustav Vasa</a> conquered the city of <a href="/wiki/Stockholm" title="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> came to Scandinavia in the 1530s, and following the <a href="/wiki/Count%27s_Feud" title="Count's Feud">Count's Feud</a> civil war, Denmark converted to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lutheranism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lutheranism (page does not exist)">Lutheranism</a> in 1536. Later that year, Denmark entered into a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Denmark-Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Denmark-Norway (page does not exist)">union with Norway</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_history_.281536.E2.80.931849.29">Early modern history (1536–1849)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Slaget_ved_oland_maleri_av_claus_moinichen_1686.jpg" title="File:Slaget ved oland maleri av claus moinichen 1686.jpg">File:Slaget ved oland maleri av claus moinichen 1686.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_%C3%96land" title="Battle of Öland">Battle of Öland</a> between an allied <a href="/w/index.php?title=Denmark%E2%80%93Norway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Denmark–Norway (page does not exist)">Dano-Norwegian</a>-<a href="/wiki/Dutch_Republic" title="Dutch Republic">Dutch</a> fleet and the Swedish navy, 1 June 1676.</div></div></div>
<p>After Sweden permanently broke away from the Kalmar Union in 1523, Denmark tried on two occasions to reassert control over Sweden. The first was in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Seven_Years_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Seven Years War (page does not exist)">Northern Seven Years War</a> which lasted from 1563 until 1570. The second occasion was the <a href="/wiki/Kalmar_War" title="Kalmar War">Kalmar War</a> when King <a href="/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark" title="Christian IV of Denmark">Christian IV</a> attacked Sweden in 1611 but failed to accomplish his main objective of forcing Sweden to return to the union with Denmark. The war led to no territorial changes, but Sweden was forced to pay a <a href="/wiki/War_reparations" title="War reparations">war indemnity</a> of 1&#160;million silver <a href="/wiki/Swedish_riksdaler" title="Swedish riksdaler">riksdaler</a> to Denmark, an amount known as the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Stettin_(1570)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Stettin (1570) (page does not exist)">Älvsborg ransom</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>King Christian used this money to found several towns and fortresses, most notably <a href="/wiki/Gl%C3%BCckstadt" title="Glückstadt">Glückstadt</a> (founded as a rival to <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>), <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">Christiania</a> (following a fire destroying the original city of <a href="/wiki/Oslo" title="Oslo">Oslo</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianshavn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianshavn (page does not exist)">Christianshavn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kristianstad" title="Kristianstad">Christianstad</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kristiansand" title="Kristiansand">Christiansand</a>. Christian also constructed a number of buildings, most notably <a href="/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen" title="Børsen">Børsen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rundet%C3%A5rn" title="Rundetårn">Rundetårn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nyboder&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nyboder (page does not exist)">Nyboder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle" title="Rosenborg Castle">Rosenborg</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Kongsberg" title="Kongsberg">silver mine</a>, and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kupferm%C3%BChle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kupfermühle (page does not exist)">copper mill</a>. Inspired by the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a>, he founded a similar <a href="/wiki/Danish_East_India_Company" title="Danish East India Company">Danish company</a> and planned to claim <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Ceylon</a> as a colony, but the company only managed to acquire <a href="/wiki/Tharangambadi" title="Tharangambadi">Tranquebar</a> on India's <a href="/wiki/Coromandel_Coast" title="Coromandel Coast">Coromandel Coast</a>. Denmark's large <a href="/wiki/Danish_colonial_empire" title="Danish colonial empire">colonial aspirations</a> were limited to a few key <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trading_posts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trading posts (page does not exist)">trading posts</a> in Africa and India.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War" title="Thirty Years' War">Thirty Years' War</a>, Christian tried to become the leader of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lutheranism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lutheranism (page does not exist)">Lutheran</a> <a href="/wiki/States_of_Germany" title="States of Germany">states in Germany</a> but suffered a crushing defeat at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Lutter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of Lutter (page does not exist)">Battle of Lutter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> The result was that the Catholic army under <a href="/wiki/Albrecht_von_Wallenstein" title="Albrecht von Wallenstein">Albrecht von Wallenstein</a> was able to invade, occupy, and pillage Jutland, forcing Denmark <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_L%C3%BCbeck&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Lübeck (page does not exist)">to withdraw from the war</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Denmark managed to avoid territorial concessions, but <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gustavus_Adolphus_of_Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden (page does not exist)">Gustavus Adolphus</a>' intervention in Germany was seen as a sign that the military power of Sweden was on the rise while Denmark's influence in the region was declining. Swedish armies <a href="/wiki/Torstenson_War" title="Torstenson War">invaded Jutland</a> in 1643 and claimed Skåne in 1644. According to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Geoffrey_Parker_(historian)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Geoffrey Parker (historian) (page does not exist)">Geoffrey Parker</a>, "The Swedish occupation caused a drop in agricultural production and a shortage of capital; harvest failure and <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">plague</a> ravaged the land between 1647 and 1651; Denmark's population fell by 20 per cent."<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Struensees_henrettelse.jpg" title="File:Struensees henrettelse.jpg">File:Struensees henrettelse.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Denmark's minister <a href="/wiki/Johann_Friedrich_Struensee" title="Johann Friedrich Struensee">Johann Struensee</a>, who abolished censorship, along with torture, unfree labor and noble privileges, was executed in 1772</div></div></div>
<p>In the 1645 <a href="/wiki/Second_Treaty_of_Br%C3%B6msebro_(1645)" title="Second Treaty of Brömsebro (1645)">Treaty of Brømsebro</a>, Denmark surrendered Halland, <a href="/wiki/Gotland" title="Gotland">Gotland</a>, the last parts of Danish Estonia, and several provinces in Norway. In 1657, King <a href="/wiki/Frederick_III_of_Denmark" title="Frederick III of Denmark">Frederick III</a> declared war on Sweden and marched on <a href="/wiki/Bremen-Verden" title="Bremen-Verden">Bremen-Verden</a>. This led to a massive Danish defeat and the armies of King <a href="/wiki/Charles_X_Gustav" title="Charles X Gustav" class="mw-redirect">Charles X Gustav</a> of Sweden conquered both <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jutland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jutland (page does not exist)">Jutland</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Funen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Funen (page does not exist)">Funen</a>, and much of <a href="/wiki/Zealand" title="Zealand">Zealand</a> before signing the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Roskilde" title="Treaty of Roskilde">Peace of Roskilde</a> in February 1658 which gave Sweden control of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sk%C3%A5ne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skåne (page does not exist)">Skåne</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blekinge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blekinge (page does not exist)">Blekinge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tr%C3%B8ndelag" title="Trøndelag">Trøndelag</a>, and the island of <a href="/wiki/Bornholm" title="Bornholm">Bornholm</a>. Charles X Gustav quickly regretted not having destroyed Denmark completely and in August 1658 he began a two-year long siege of <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> but failed to take the capital. In the following peace settlement, Denmark managed to maintain its independence and regain control of Trøndelag and Bornholm.
</p><p>Denmark tried to regain control of Skåne in the <a href="/wiki/Scanian_War" title="Scanian War">Scanian War</a> (1675–1679) but this attempt was a failure. Following the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a> (1700–1721), Denmark managed to restore control of the parts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schleswig&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schleswig (page does not exist)">Schleswig</a> and <a href="/wiki/Holstein" title="Holstein">Holstein</a> ruled by the house of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holstein-Gottorp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holstein-Gottorp (page does not exist)">Holstein-Gottorp</a> in 1721 and 1773, respectively. In the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, Denmark originally tried to pursue a policy of neutrality and trade with both <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_French_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First French Empire (page does not exist)">France</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom</a> and joined the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_League_of_Armed_Neutrality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second League of Armed Neutrality (page does not exist)">League of Armed Neutrality</a> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian Empire (page does not exist)">Russia</a>, Sweden, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Prussia</a>. The British considered this a hostile act and attacked Copenhagen in both <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Copenhagen_(1801)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of Copenhagen (1801) (page does not exist)">1801</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Copenhagen_(1807)" title="Battle of Copenhagen (1807)">1807</a>, in one case carrying off the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy" title="Royal Danish Navy">Danish fleet</a>, in the other, burning large parts of Copenhagen.
</p><p>This led to the so-called Danish-British <a href="/wiki/Gunboat_War" title="Gunboat War">Gunboat War</a>. The British control of the waterways between Denmark and Norway proved disastrous to the union's economy and in 1813, Denmark-Norway went <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy" title="Bankruptcy">bankrupt</a>. The Danish-Norwegian union was dissolved by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Kiel" title="Treaty of Kiel">Treaty of Kiel</a> in 1814. Norway entered a new union with Sweden which lasted until 1905. Denmark kept the colonies of <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>. Apart from the Nordic colonies, Denmark ruled over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish India (page does not exist)">Danish India</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Tranquebar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tranquebar (page does not exist)">Tranquebar</a> in India) from 1620 to 1869, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Gold_Coast&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Gold Coast (page does not exist)">Danish Gold Coast</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>) from 1658 to 1850, and the <a href="/wiki/Danish_West_Indies" title="Danish West Indies">Danish West Indies</a> (the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands" title="United States Virgin Islands">U.S. Virgin Islands</a>) from 1671 to 1917.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constitutional_monarchy_.281849.E2.80.93present.29">Constitutional monarchy (1849–present)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Grundlovgivende_rigsforsamling_-_Constantin_Hansen.jpg" title="File:Grundlovgivende rigsforsamling - Constantin Hansen.jpg">File:Grundlovgivende rigsforsamling - Constantin Hansen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Den Grundlovsgivende Rigsforsamling</i> – The Constitutional Assembly of the Realm was assembled by King <a href="/wiki/Frederick_VII_of_Denmark" title="Frederick VII of Denmark">Frederick VII</a> in 1848 to adopt the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Denmark" title="Constitution of Denmark">Constitution of Denmark</a></div></div></div>
<p>A nascent Danish liberal and national movement gained momentum in the 1830s; after the European <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revolutions_of_1848&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revolutions of 1848 (page does not exist)">Revolutions of 1848</a>, Denmark peacefully became a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> on 5 June 1849. A two-chamber parliament was established. After the <a href="/wiki/Second_Schleswig_War" title="Second Schleswig War">Second War of Schleswig</a> in 1864, Denmark was forced to cede <a href="/w/index.php?title=Province_of_Schleswig-Holstein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Province of Schleswig-Holstein (page does not exist)">Schleswig and Holstein</a> to <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a>, in a defeat that left deep marks on the Danish national identity.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} After these events, Denmark pursued a policy of neutrality in Europe.
</p><p>Denmark remained neutral during <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>. After the defeat of Germany, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Versailles powers</a> offered to return the region of Schleswig-Holstein to Denmark. Fearing German <a href="/wiki/Irredentism" title="Irredentism">irredentism</a>, Denmark refused to consider the return of the area without a <a href="/wiki/Plebiscite" title="Plebiscite" class="mw-redirect">plebiscite</a>. The two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schleswig_Plebiscites&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schleswig Plebiscites (page does not exist)">Schleswig Plebiscites</a> took place on 10 February and 14 March 1920, respectively. On 10 July 1920, Northern Schleswig (Sønderjylland) was recovered by Denmark, thereby adding some 163,600 inhabitants and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The reunion day (<i>Genforeningsdag</i>) is celebrated every 15 June on <i>Valdemarsdag</i>.
</p><p>Denmark signed a 10-year non-aggression pact with <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> in 1939. Germany's <a href="/wiki/Invasion" title="Invasion">invasion</a> of Denmark on 9 April 1940 – code-named <a href="/w/index.php?title=Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Operation Weserübung (page does not exist)">Operation Weserübung</a> – met only two hours of military resistance before the Danish government surrendered. Economic co-operation between Germany and Denmark continued until 1943, when the Danish government refused further co-operation and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy" title="Royal Danish Navy">its navy</a> scuttled most of its ships and sent as many of their officers as they could to Sweden.
</p><p>During the war, the government was helpful towards the Danish Jewish minority and the Danish resistance performed a daring <a href="/wiki/Rescue_of_the_Danish_Jews" title="Rescue of the Danish Jews">rescue operation</a> that managed to get most of them to Sweden and safety shortly before the Germans planned to round up the Danish Jews. Danish doctors refused to treat German citizens fleeing from Germany, which resulted in the deaths of 13,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Danish citizens volunteered to fight Russia in co-operation with Germany as part of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frikorps_Danmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frikorps Danmark (page does not exist)">Frikorps Danmark</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> severed ties to Denmark and became an independent republic in 1944; in 1948, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a> gained <a href="/wiki/Home_rule" title="Home rule">home rule</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-war_.281945.E2.80.93present.29">Post-war (1945–present)</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" title="File:Tratado de Lisboa 13 12 2007 (081).jpg">File:Tratado de Lisboa 13 12 2007 (081).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Denmark became a member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 1973 and signed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lisbon_Treaty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lisbon Treaty (page does not exist)">Lisbon Treaty</a> in 2007.</div></div></div>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Denmark became one of the founding members of the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">European Free Trade Association</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>. During the 1960s, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=EFTA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="EFTA (page does not exist)">EFTA</a> countries were often referred to as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Outer_Seven&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Outer Seven (page does not exist)">Outer Seven</a>, as opposed to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inner_Six&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inner Six (page does not exist)">Inner Six</a> of what was then the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC).<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1973, along with Britain and Ireland, Denmark joined the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> after a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_European_Communities_membership_referendum,_1972&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish European Communities membership referendum, 1972 (page does not exist)">public referendum</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_treaty" title="Maastricht treaty" class="mw-redirect">Maastricht treaty</a>, which involved further European integration, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Maastricht_Treaty_referendum,_1992&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Maastricht Treaty referendum, 1992 (page does not exist)">was rejected</a> by the Danish people in 1992; it was only accepted after a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Maastricht_Treaty_referendum,_1993&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Maastricht Treaty referendum, 1993 (page does not exist)">second referendum</a> in 1993 and the addition of certain opt-out provisions for Denmark. The Danes rejected the euro as the national currency in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_euro_referendum,_2000&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish euro referendum, 2000 (page does not exist)">a referendum in 2000</a>. <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> gained <a href="/wiki/Home_rule" title="Home rule">home rule</a> in 1979 and was awarded <a href="/wiki/Self-determination" title="Self-determination">self-determination</a> in 2009. Neither Greenland nor the Faroe Islands are members of the European Union, the Faroese having declined membership of the EEC in 1973 and Greenland in 1986, in both cases because of fisheries policies.
</p><p>Constitutional change in 1953 led to a single-chamber parliament elected by proportional representation, female accession to the Danish throne, and Greenland becoming an integral part of Denmark. The <a href="/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Denmark)" title="Social Democrats (Denmark)">Social Democrats</a> led a string of coalition governments for most of the second half of the 20th century in a country generally known for its liberal traditions. <a href="/wiki/Poul_Schluter" title="Poul Schluter" class="mw-redirect">Poul Schluter</a> then became the first Danish prime minister from the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_People%27s_Party_(Denmark)" title="Conservative People's Party (Denmark)">Conservative People's Party</a> in 1982, leading a centre-right coalition until 1993, when he was succeeded by the Social Democrat <a href="/wiki/Poul_Nyrup_Rasmussen" title="Poul Nyrup Rasmussen">Poul Nyrup Rasmussen</a>.
</p><p>A centre-right coalition, headed by <a href="/wiki/Anders_Fogh_Rasmussen" title="Anders Fogh Rasmussen">Anders Fogh Rasmussen</a>, came to power in 2001 promising tighter immigration controls. A third successive centre-right leader, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lars_L%C3%B8kke_Rasmussen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lars Løkke Rasmussen (page does not exist)">Lars Løkke Rasmussen</a>, was prime minister from 2009 to 2011 due to <a href="/wiki/Anders_Fogh_Rasmussen" title="Anders Fogh Rasmussen">Anders Fogh Rasmussen</a> resigning as Prime Minister of Denmark to become the Secretary General of NATO. The Rasmussen governments were dependent on the right-wing populist <a href="/wiki/Danish_People%27s_Party" title="Danish People's Party">Danish People's Party</a> throughout the 2000s to push through legislation, during which time immigration and integration emerged as major issues of public debate. <a href="/wiki/Helle_Thorning-Schmidt" title="Helle Thorning-Schmidt">Helle Thorning-Schmidt</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Denmark)" title="Social Democrats (Denmark)">Social Democrats</a> became Denmark's first female prime minister in 2011, ending a decade of centre-right rule.
</p><p>Despite its modest size, Denmark has participated in generally UN-sanctioned, and often NATO-led, military and humanitarian operations, including: <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_War" title="Bosnian War">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Egypt</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Croatian_War_of_Independence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Croatian War of Independence (page does not exist)">Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo</a>, Ethiopia, <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present) (page does not exist)">Afghanistan</a>, Iraq, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Somali_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Somali Civil War (page does not exist)">Somalia</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_military_intervention_in_Libya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 military intervention in Libya (page does not exist)">Libya</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_of_Denmark">Geography of Denmark</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Denmark_in_July_2001.jpg" title="File:Satellite image of Denmark in July 2001.jpg">File:Satellite image of Denmark in July 2001.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A satellite image of metropolitan Denmark.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>Located in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Europe" title="Northern Europe">Northern Europe</a>, Denmark consists of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_peninsulas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of peninsulas (page does not exist)">peninsula</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jutland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jutland (page does not exist)">Jutland</a> and 443 named islands (1,419 islands above <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in total).<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Of these, 72 are inhabited,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> with the largest being <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zealand_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zealand (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Zealand</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Funen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Funen (page does not exist)">Funen</a>. The island of <a href="/wiki/Bornholm" title="Bornholm">Bornholm</a> is located east of the rest of the country, in the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>. Many of the larger islands are connected by bridges; the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge" title="Øresund Bridge">Øresund Bridge</a> connects Zealand with Sweden; the <a href="/wiki/Great_Belt_Fixed_Link" title="Great Belt Fixed Link">Great Belt Bridge</a> connects Funen with Zealand; and the <a href="/wiki/Little_Belt_Bridge_(1970)" title="Little Belt Bridge (1970)">Little Belt Bridge</a> connects Jutland with Funen. <a href="/wiki/Ferry" title="Ferry">Ferries</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Small_aircraft&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Small aircraft (page does not exist)">small aircraft</a> connect to the smaller islands. The largest cities with populations over 100,000 are the capital <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> on Zealand; <a href="/wiki/Aarhus" title="Aarhus">Aarhus</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aalborg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aalborg (page does not exist)">Aalborg</a> in Jutland; and <a href="/wiki/Odense" title="Odense">Odense</a> on Funen.
</p><p>Denmark occupies an area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mundi_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mundi-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-factbook_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-48">[48]</a></sup> The size of the land area of Denmark cannot be stated exactly since the ocean constantly erodes and adds material to the coastline, and because of human <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">land reclamation</a> projects (to counter erosion). It shares a border of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> with Germany to the south and is otherwise surrounded by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of tidal <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shoreline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shoreline (page does not exist)">shoreline</a> (including small <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bay (page does not exist)">bays</a> and <a href="/wiki/Inlet" title="Inlet">inlets</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Nature_and_Environment_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nature_and_Environment-49">[49]</a></sup> No location in Denmark is further from the coast than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. On the south-west coast of Jutland, the tide is between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, and the tideline moves outward and inward on a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> stretch.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Denmark's northernmost point is <a href="/wiki/Skagen" title="Skagen">Skagen</a>'s point (the north beach of the Skaw) at 57° 45' 7" northern latitude; the southernmost is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gedser&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gedser (page does not exist)">Gedser</a> point (the southern tip of <a href="/wiki/Falster" title="Falster">Falster</a>) at 54° 33' 35" northern latitude; the westernmost point is <a href="/wiki/Bl%C3%A5vandshuk" title="Blåvandshuk">Blåvandshuk</a> at 8° 4' 22" eastern longitude; and the easternmost point is <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%98stersk%C3%A6r&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Østerskær (page does not exist)">Østerskær</a> at 15° 11' 55" eastern longitude. This is in the archipelago <a href="/wiki/Ertholmene" title="Ertholmene">Ertholmene</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> north-east of <a href="/wiki/Bornholm" title="Bornholm">Bornholm</a>. The distance from east to west is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, from north to south <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.
</p><p>The country is flat with little elevation; having an average height <a href="/w/index.php?title=Above_mean_sea_level&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Above mean sea level (page does not exist)">above sea level</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The highest natural point is <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B8lleh%C3%B8j" title="Møllehøj">Møllehøj</a>, at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. The area of inland water is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Phytogeography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phytogeography (page does not exist)">Phytogeographically</a>, the Kingdom of Denmark (including Greenland and the Faroe Islands) belongs to the <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">Boreal Kingdom</a> and is shared between the <a href="/wiki/Arctic" title="Arctic">Arctic</a>, Atlantic European, and Central European provinces of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Circumboreal_Region&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Circumboreal Region (page does not exist)">Circumboreal Region</a>. According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Wide Fund for Nature (page does not exist)">World Wide Fund for Nature</a>, the territory of metropolitan Denmark can be subdivided into two <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregions</a>: the Atlantic mixed forests and Baltic mixed forests. The Faroe Islands are covered by the Faroe Islands boreal grasslands, while Greenland hosts the ecoregions of Kalaallit Nunaat high arctic tundra and Kalaallit Nunaat low arctic tundra.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p>Denmark has a <a href="/wiki/Temperateness" title="Temperateness" class="mw-redirect">temperate</a> climate, characterised by mild winters, with mean temperatures in January and February of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, and cool summers, with a mean temperature in August of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Denmark_climate_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Denmark_climate-51">[51]</a></sup> Denmark has an average of 121 days per year with precipitation, on average receiving a total of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> per year; autumn is the wettest season and spring the driest.<sup id="cite_ref-Denmark_climate_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Denmark_climate-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of Denmark's northern location, there are large seasonal variations in daylight. There are short days during the winter with sunrise coming around 8:45&#160;am and sunset 3:45&#160;pm (standard time), as well as long summer days with sunrise at 4:30&#160;am and sunset at 10&#160;pm (<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">daylight saving time</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-sunrise_sunset_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sunrise_sunset-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Faroe Islands has a mean temperature in January of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, in July the mean temperature was 10.1 in 2012 and all that year it was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. In 2012 the Faroe Islands had 195 days with precipitation and received a total of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> that year.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>
<p>Denmark has historically taken a progressive stance on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_preservation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental preservation (page does not exist)">environmental preservation</a>; in 1971 Denmark established a Ministry of Environment and was the first country in the world to implement an <a href="/wiki/Environmental_law" title="Environmental law">environmental law</a> in 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> To mitigate environmental degradation and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">global warming</a> the Danish Government has signed the following international agreements: Antarctic Treaty; <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol</a> etc.<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen is the spearhead of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bright_green_environmentalism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bright green environmentalism (page does not exist)">bright green</a> <a href="/wiki/Environmental_movement" title="Environmental movement">environmental movement</a> in Denmark.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Copenhagen's most important environment research institutions are the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School" title="Copenhagen Business School">Copenhagen Business School</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ris%C3%B8_DTU_National_Laboratory_for_Sustainable_Energy" title="Risø DTU National Laboratory for Sustainable Energy">Risø DTU National Laboratory for Sustainable Energy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark" title="Technical University of Denmark">Technical University of Denmark</a>, which Risø is now part of. Leading up to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference</a> (Copenhagen Summit), the University of Copenhagen held the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Climate_Change:_Global_Risks,_Challenges_and_Decisions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Climate Change: Global Risks, Challenges and Decisions (page does not exist)">Climate Change: Global Risks, Challenges and Decisions</a> conference where the need for comprehensive action to mitigate <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> was stressed by the international <a href="/wiki/Scientific_community" title="Scientific community">scientific community</a>. Notable figures such as <a href="/wiki/Rajendra_K._Pachauri" title="Rajendra K. Pachauri">Rajendra K. Pachauri</a>, Chairman of the IPCC, Professor <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Stern,_Baron_Stern_of_Brentford" title="Nicholas Stern, Baron Stern of Brentford">Nicholas Stern</a>, author of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stern_Review&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stern Review (page does not exist)">Stern Report</a>, and Professor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daniel_Kammen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daniel Kammen (page does not exist)">Daniel Kammen</a> all emphasised the good example set by Copenhagen and Denmark in capitalising on cleantech and achieving economic growth while stabilising <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">carbon emissions</a>.
</p><p>Denmark's green house gas emissions per dollar of value produced has been for the most part unstable since 1990, seeing sudden growths and falls. Overall though, there has been a reduction in gas emissions per dollar value added to its market.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> It lags behind other Scandinavian countries such as Norway<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> and Sweden.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Governance">Governance</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>The Kingdom of Denmark is a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>, in which <a href="/wiki/Margrethe_II_of_Denmark" title="Margrethe II of Denmark">Queen Margrethe II</a> is head of state, but royal power has long been limited to ceremonial functions.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> The monarch is not answerable for his or her actions, and the monarch's person is sacrosanct.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Danish political system operates under a framework laid out in the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Denmark" title="Constitution of Denmark">Constitution of Denmark</a>. Changes to it require an absolute majority in two consecutive parliamentary terms and majority approval through a referendum (and the referendum majority must constitute at least 40 per cent of the electorate).<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>  The Constitution lays out a political system based on the separation of powers into the three branches of government; the legislative, the executive, and the judiciary branches.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_system">Political system</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Det_danske_parlament.jpg" title="File:Det danske parlament.jpg">File:Det danske parlament.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The debating chamber of the national <a href="/wiki/Parliament" title="Parliament">parliament</a>, the <i>Folketing</i>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Folketing" title="Folketing">Folketing</a> is the national <a href="/wiki/Parliament" title="Parliament">Parliament</a>, the supreme <a href="/wiki/Legislative_body" title="Legislative body" class="mw-redirect">legislative body</a> of the kingdom. In theory it has the ultimate legislative authority according to the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_sovereignty" title="Parliamentary sovereignty">parliamentary sovereignty</a>, it is able to legislate on any matter and not bound by decisions of its predecessors. However questions over sovereignty have been brought forward because of Denmark's entry into the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.  Parliament consists of 175 members elected by proportional majority, plus two members each from Greenland and the Faroe Islands.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> Parliamentary elections are held at least every four years, but it is within the powers of the Prime Minister to ask the monarch to call for an election before the term has elapsed. On a <a href="/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence" title="Motion of no confidence">vote of no confidence</a>, the Parliament may force a single Minister or the entire government to resign.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Danish political system has traditionally generated coalitions. Most Danish post-war governments have been minority coalitions ruling with the support of non-government parties.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Denmark" title="Prime Minister of Denmark">Prime Minister</a> is formally appointed by the monarch, on the advice of party leaders following an election or collapse of a government. In practice the Prime Minister is chosen through negotiation between the parliament party leaders, customarily with the leader of the largest party in a coalition being appointed. Executive authority is exercised on behalf of the monarch by the Prime Minister and other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cabinet_of_Helle_Thorning-Schmidt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cabinet of Helle Thorning-Schmidt (page does not exist)">cabinet ministers</a> who head <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Danish_government_ministries,_past_and_present&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Danish government ministries, past and present (page does not exist)">departments</a>. The Cabinet, Prime Minister and other Ministers collectively make up the government of Denmark.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lars_L%C3%B8kke_Rasmussen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lars Løkke Rasmussen (page does not exist)">Lars Løkke Rasmussen</a> was the Prime minister from April 2009 until September 2011. He headed a right-wing government coalition consisting of <a href="/wiki/Venstre_(Denmark)" title="Venstre (Denmark)">Venstre</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Conservative_liberalism" title="Conservative liberalism">conservative liberal</a> party) and the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_People%27s_Party_(Denmark)" title="Conservative People's Party (Denmark)">Conservative People's Party</a>, with parliamentary support from the national-conservative <a href="/wiki/Danish_People%27s_Party" title="Danish People's Party">Danish People's Party</a>. Following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_general_election,_2011&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish general election, 2011 (page does not exist)">September 2011 election</a> the right wing lost by a small margin to the opposing left-wing coalition, led by <a href="/wiki/Helle_Thorning-Schmidt" title="Helle Thorning-Schmidt">Helle Thorning-Schmidt</a>, who on 3 October 2011 formed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cabinet_of_Helle_Thorning-Schmidt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cabinet of Helle Thorning-Schmidt (page does not exist)">new government</a> consisting of the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Denmark)" title="Social Democrats (Denmark)">Social Democrats</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Social_Liberal_Party" title="Danish Social Liberal Party">Danish Social Liberal Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_People%27s_Party_(Denmark)" title="Socialist People's Party (Denmark)">Socialist People's Party</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Judicial_system">Judicial system</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Judicial authority remains separate from the executive and legislature and lies with the <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_Denmark" title="Courts of Denmark">courts of justice</a>. The Kingdom of Denmark does not have a single unified judicial system – Denmark proper has one system, Greenland another, and the Faroe Islands a third.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> However, decisions by the highest courts in Greenland and the Faroe Islands may be appealed to the Danish High Courts. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Supreme_Court_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Supreme Court of Denmark (page does not exist)">Danish Supreme Court</a> is the highest civil and criminal court responsible for the administration of justice in the kingdom.
</p><p>Articles 62 and 64 of the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Constitution" title="Danish Constitution" class="mw-redirect">Danish Constitution</a> ensure <a href="/wiki/Judicial_independence" title="Judicial independence">judicial independence</a> from Government and Parliament by providing that judges shall only be guided by the law, including acts, statutes and practice.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations_and_military">Foreign relations and military</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Danish foreign policy is based on its identity as a sovereign nation in Europe. As such its primary foreign policy focus is on its relations with other nations as a sovereign independent nation. Denmark has long had good relations with other nations. It has been involved in coordinating Western assistance to the Baltic states (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estonia (page does not exist)">Estonia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Denmark ended its two-hundred-year policy of neutrality. Denmark has been a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> since its founding in 1949, and membership in NATO remains highly popular.<sup id="cite_ref-stategov_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stategov-70">[70]</a></sup> There were several serious confrontations between the U.S. and Denmark on security policy in the so-called "footnote era" (1982–88), when an alternative parliamentary majority forced the government to adopt specific national positions on nuclear and arms control issues.<sup id="cite_ref-stategov_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stategov-70">[70]</a></sup> With the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, however, Denmark has been supportive of U.S. policy objectives in the Alliance.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Danish_Military_Police.JPG" title="File:Danish Military Police.JPG">File:Danish Military Police.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Danish MP-soldiers conducting advanced law enforcement training.</div></div></div>
<p>Denmark's armed forces are known as the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Defence" title="Danish Defence">Danish Defence</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>). During peacetime, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ministry_of_Defence_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ministry of Defence (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Ministry of Defence in Denmark</a> employs around 33,000 in total. The main military branches employ almost 27,000: 15,460 in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Army&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Army (page does not exist)">Danish Army</a>, 5,300 in the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy" title="Royal Danish Navy">Royal Danish Navy</a> and 6,050 in the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Danish_Air_Force" title="Royal Danish Air Force">Royal Danish Air Force</a> (all including conscripts).
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Emergency_Management_Agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Emergency Management Agency (page does not exist)">Danish Emergency Management Agency</a> (<span lang="da"><i>Beredskabsstyrelsen</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>) employs 2,000 (including conscripts), and about 4,000 are in non-branch-specific services like the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Defence_Command_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Defence Command (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Danish Defence Command</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Defence_Research_Establishment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Defence Research Establishment (page does not exist)">Danish Defence Research Establishment</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Defence_Intelligence_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Defence Intelligence Service (page does not exist)">Danish Defence Intelligence Service</a>. Furthermore around 55,000 serve as volunteers in the <a href="/wiki/Home_Guard_(Denmark)" title="Home Guard (Denmark)">Danish Home Guard</a> (<span lang="da"><i>Hjemmeværnet</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>).
</p><p>The country is a strong supporter of international <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a>. The Danish Defence has around 1,400<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> staff in international missions, not including standing contributions to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Standing_NRF_Mine_Countermeasures_Group_1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Standing NRF Mine Countermeasures Group 1 (page does not exist)">NATO SNMCMG1</a>. The three largest contributions are in <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> (<a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">ISAF</a>), <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">KFOR</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> (<a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Force_in_Lebanon" title="United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon">UNIFIL</a>). Between 2003 and 2007, there were approximately 450 Danish soldiers in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq (page does not exist)">Iraq</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>Denmark is today pursuing an active foreign policy, where human rights, democracy and other crucial values are to be defended actively. In recent years <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Faroe_Islands" title="The Faroe Islands" class="mw-redirect">The Faroe Islands</a> have been guaranteed a say in foreign policy issues such as fishing, <a href="/wiki/Whaling" title="Whaling">whaling</a>, and geopolitical concerns.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-begin (page does not exist)">Template:Col-begin</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-break&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-break (page does not exist)">Template:Col-break</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Denmark proper is divided into five <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regions_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regions of Denmark (page does not exist)">regions</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>, singular: <i>region</i>) and a total of 98 <a href="/wiki/List_of_municipalities_of_Denmark" title="List of municipalities of Denmark">municipalities</a>. The regions were created on 1 January 2007 to replace the <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Denmark" title="Counties of Denmark">former counties</a>. At the same time, smaller municipalities were merged into larger units, cutting the number of municipalities from 270 to 98. Most municipalities have a population of at least 20,000 people to give them financial and professional sustainability, although a few exceptions were made to this rule.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most important area of responsibility for regions is the national health service. Unlike the former counties, the regions are not allowed to levy taxes, and the <a href="/wiki/Health_care" title="Health care">health service</a> is primarily financed by a national health care contribution of eight per cent (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>) combined with funds from both government and municipalities.<sup id="cite_ref-expat_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-expat-74">[74]</a></sup>  Municipalities and regions are led by directly elected councils, elected every four years. The last <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_local_elections,_2013&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish local elections, 2013 (page does not exist)">Danish local elections</a> were held on 19 November 2013.
</p><p>The easternmost land in Denmark, the <a href="/wiki/Ertholmene" title="Ertholmene">Ertholmene</a> archipelago, with a population of 92 (2013) and area of 39 hectares, is neither part of a municipality nor a region but belongs to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ministry_of_Defence_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ministry of Defence (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Ministry of Defence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-break&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-break (page does not exist)">Template:Col-break</a>
</p>
<div style="float:right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Danish_regions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Danish regions (page does not exist)">Template:Danish regions</a></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-end (page does not exist)">Template:Col-end</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">

<tr>

<td style="text-align:right;"> 112.32 </td>

<tr>
<td> Region Syddanmark </td>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Region_of_Southern_Denmark" title="Region of Southern Denmark">Region of Southern Denmark</a> </td>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Vejle" title="Vejle">Vejle</a> </td>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Odense" title="Odense">Odense</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 1,201,955 </td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 12,132.21 </td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 99.07 </td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 22 <a href="/wiki/List_of_municipalities_of_Denmark#Region_of_Southern_Denmark" title="List of municipalities of Denmark">(list)</a>
</td></tr></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Greenland_and_the_Faroe_Islands">Greenland and the Faroe Islands</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Kingdom of Denmark is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a>, however the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> were granted <a href="/wiki/Home_rule" title="Home rule">home rule</a> (political autonomy)<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>  in 1948 and 1979 respectively, having previously had the status of counties.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-stm_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stm-78">[78]</a></sup>  Extensive powers have been <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> to the Faroe Islands and Greenland, which have their own governments and legislatures and are effectively <a href="/w/index.php?title=Self-governing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Self-governing (page does not exist)">self-governing</a> in regards to domestic affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-stm_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stm-78">[78]</a></sup> However, the devolved legislatures are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Folketing" title="Folketing">Folketing</a> where the two territories are represented by two seats each. <a href="/wiki/High_Commissioner" title="High Commissioner">High Commissioners</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>) act as representatives of the Danish government in the Faroese Løgting and in the Parliament of Greenland, but they can not vote.<sup id="cite_ref-stm_78-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stm-78">[78]</a></sup> The Faroese government is defined to be an equal partner with the Danish governemt in the act of 2005 (Act on the Faroese authorities acquisition of affairs and fields)<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> and the Greenlandic people are defined as a separate people with the right to <a href="/wiki/Self-determination" title="Self-determination">self-determination</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
