<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lego_Color_Bricks.jpg" title="File:Lego Color Bricks.jpg">File:Lego Color Bricks.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=LEGO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="LEGO (page does not exist)">LEGO</a> bricks are produced by the LEGO company, headquartered in <a href="/wiki/Billund,_Denmark" title="Billund, Denmark">Billund</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Denmark has a modern, prosperous and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Developed_economy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Developed economy (page does not exist)">developed</a> <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed market</a> economy, ranking 21st in the world in terms of <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP (PPP) per capita</a> and 10th in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">nominal GDP per capita</a>.  A liberalisation of import tariffs in 1797 marked the end of <a href="/wiki/Mercantilism" title="Mercantilism">mercantilism</a> and further liberalisation in the 19th and the beginning of the 20th century established the Danish liberal tradition in international trade that was only to be broken by the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Property_rights" title="Property rights" class="mw-redirect">Property rights</a> have enjoyed strong protection. Denmark's economy stands out as one of the most free in the <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">Index of Economic Freedom</a><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economic_Freedom_of_the_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economic Freedom of the World (page does not exist)">Economic Freedom of the World</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2011-09-20_fraserinstitute_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011-09-20_fraserinstitute-85">[85]</a></sup> The economy has high levels of <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">international trade</a> and Denmark is known as a free trade advocate in the European Union. Denmark is one of the most competitive economies in the world according to <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a> 2008 report, IMD and <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a result of its acclaimed "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Flexicurity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flexicurity (page does not exist)">flexicurity</a>" model, Denmark has the most free <a href="/wiki/Labour_economics" title="Labour economics">labour market</a> in Europe, according to the World Bank. Employers can hire and fire whenever they want (flexibility), and between jobs, unemployment compensation is very high (security). The World Bank ranks Denmark as the easiest place in Europe to do business. Establishing a business can be done in a matter of hours and at very low costs.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> Denmark has a competitive <a href="/wiki/Corporate_tax" title="Corporate tax">company tax</a> rate of 25% and a special time-limited tax regime for expatriates.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> The Danish taxation system is broad based, with a 25% <a href="/wiki/VAT" title="VAT" class="mw-redirect">VAT</a>, in addition to excise taxes, income taxes and other fees. The overall tax burden (sum of all taxes, as a percentage of GDP) is estimated to be 46% in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>Denmark has a <a href="/wiki/Labour_force" title="Labour force" class="mw-redirect">labour force</a> of about 2.9&#160;million. Denmark has the fourth highest ratio of <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary degree</a> holders in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_hour_worked&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per hour worked (page does not exist)">GDP per hour worked</a> was the 13th highest in 2009. Denmark has <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_income_equality" title="List of countries by income equality">the world's lowest level of income inequality</a>, according to the World Bank Gini (%),<sup id="cite_ref-wbg_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wbg-91">[91]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_minimum_wages_by_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of minimum wages by country (page does not exist)">the world's highest minimum wage</a>, according to the IMF.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> In July 2013 the unemployment rate was at 6.7%, which was below the EU average of 10.9%.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Euro_accession.svg" title="File:Euro accession.svg">File:Euro accession.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Denmark is part of the Schengen Area and the EU single market, although it has opted out of the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Denmark's currency, the <i><a href="/wiki/Danish_krone" title="Danish krone">krone</a></i>, is <a href="/wiki/Fixed_exchange_rate" title="Fixed exchange rate">pegged</a> at approximately 7.46 kroner per euro through the <a href="/wiki/European_Exchange_Rate_Mechanism" title="European Exchange Rate Mechanism">ERM</a>. Although a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_euro_referendum,_2000&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish euro referendum, 2000 (page does not exist)">September 2000 referendum</a> rejected adopting the euro,<sup id="cite_ref-denmarkandtheeuro_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-denmarkandtheeuro-94">[94]</a></sup> the country in practice follows the policies set forth in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economic_and_Monetary_Union_of_the_European_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union (page does not exist)">Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union</a> and meets the economic <a href="/wiki/Euro_convergence_criteria" title="Euro convergence criteria">convergence criteria</a> needed to adopt the euro. The majority of the political parties in the parliament are for the euro, but as yet a new referendum has not been held, despite plans;<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> scepticism of the EU among Danish voters has historically been strong. Denmark is known for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_cooperative_movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish cooperative movement (page does not exist)">Danish cooperative movement</a> within among others farming, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food industry (page does not exist)">food industry</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Crown_AmbA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Crown AmbA (page does not exist)">Danish Crown</a>), dairy production (<a href="/wiki/Arla_Foods" title="Arla Foods">Arla Foods</a>), retailing (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Brugsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brugsen (page does not exist)">Brugsen</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Community_wind_energy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Community wind energy (page does not exist)">wind turbine cooperatives</a> and co-housing associations.
</p><p>Support for <a href="/wiki/Free_trade" title="Free trade">free trade</a> is high – in a 2007 poll 76% responded that globalisation is a good thing.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> 70% of trade flows are inside the European Union.
Denmark has the 9th highest <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_exports_per_capita&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by exports per capita (page does not exist)">export per capita in the world</a>. Denmark's main exports are: industrial production/manufactured goods 73.3% (of which machinery and instruments were 21.4%, and fuels (oil, natural gas), chemicals, etc. 26%); agricultural products and others for consumption 18.7% (in 2009 meat and meat products were 5.5% of total export; fish and fish products 2.9%).<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_48-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-48">[48]</a></sup> Denmark is a net exporter of food and energy and has for a number of years had a <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_payments" title="Balance of payments">balance of payments</a> surplus while battling an equivalent of approximately 39% of GNP <a href="/wiki/External_debt" title="External debt">foreign debt</a> or more than 300&#160;billion DKK.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=StatBank&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="StatBank (page does not exist)">StatBank</a> is the name of a large statistical database maintained by the central authority of statistics in Denmark. Online distribution of statistics has been a part of the dissemination strategy in Denmark since 1985. By this service, Denmark is a leading country in the world regarding electronic dissemination of statistics. There are about 2&#160;million hits every year.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DanishWindTurbines.jpg" title="File:DanishWindTurbines.jpg">File:DanishWindTurbines.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Offshore wind turbines near <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Denmark has considerable sources of oil and natural gas in the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> and ranks as number 32 in the world among net exporters of <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">crude oil</a><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> and was producing 259,980 barrels of crude oil a day in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> Most electricity is produced from coal, but 25–28% of electricity demand is supplied through wind turbines.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Denmark is a long-time leader in wind energy, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> Denmark derived 3.1% of its gross domestic product from renewable (clean) energy technology and energy efficiency, or around €6.5&#160;billion ($9.4&#160;billion).<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> Denmark is connected by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electric_transmission_lines&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electric transmission lines (page does not exist)">electric transmission lines</a> to other European countries. On 6 September 2012, Denmark launched the biggest wind turbine in the world, and will add four more over the next four years.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Electricity_sector_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electricity sector in Denmark (page does not exist)">Denmark's electricity sector</a> has integrated energy sources such as wind power into the national grid. Denmark now aims to focus on intelligent battery systems (<a href="/wiki/Vehicle-to-grid" title="Vehicle-to-grid">V2G</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle" title="Electric vehicle">plug-in vehicles</a> in the transport sector.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Airport_Mai_2009_PD_131.JPG" title="File:Copenhagen Airport Mai 2009 PD 131.JPG">File:Copenhagen Airport Mai 2009 PD 131.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport</a> is the largest airport in Scandinavia and 15th busiest in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Significant investment has been made in building road and rail links between regions in Denmark, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Great_Belt_Fixed_Link" title="Great Belt Fixed Link">Great Belt Fixed Link</a>, which connects <a href="/w/index.php?title=Zealand_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zealand (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Zealand</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Funen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Funen (page does not exist)">Funen</a>. It is now possible to drive from <a href="/wiki/Frederikshavn" title="Frederikshavn">Frederikshavn</a> in northern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jutland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jutland (page does not exist)">Jutland</a> to <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> on eastern Zealand without leaving the motorway. The main railway operator is <a href="/wiki/DSB_(railway_company)" title="DSB (railway company)">DSB</a> for passenger services and <a href="/wiki/DB_Schenker_Rail" title="DB Schenker Rail">DB Schenker Rail</a> for freight trains. The railway tracks are maintained by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Banedanmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Banedanmark (page does not exist)">Banedanmark</a>.
</p><p>Copenhagen has a small Metro system, the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro" title="Copenhagen Metro">Copenhagen Metro</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greater_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greater Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Greater Copenhagen</a> area has an extensive electrified suburban railway network, the <a href="/wiki/S-train" title="S-train">S-train</a>. Denmark's <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">national airline</a> (together with Norway and Sweden) is <a href="/wiki/Scandinavian_Airlines" title="Scandinavian Airlines">Scandinavian Airlines</a> (SAS), and <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport" title="Copenhagen Airport">Copenhagen Airport</a> is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_the_largest_airports_in_the_Nordic_countries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of the largest airports in the Nordic countries (page does not exist)">largest</a> in Scandinavia. A ferry link to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Faroe_Islands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Faroe Islands (page does not exist)">Faroe Islands</a> is maintained by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smyril_Line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smyril Line (page does not exist)">Smyril Line</a>. Other international ferry services are mainly operated by <a href="/wiki/DFDS" title="DFDS">DFDS</a> (to Norway and the UK), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scandlines&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scandlines (page does not exist)">Scandlines</a> (to Germany and Sweden), <a href="/wiki/Stena_Line" title="Stena Line">Stena Line</a> (to Norway, Sweden and Poland), Color Line (to Norway), and FjordLine (to Norway).
</p><p>Private vehicles are increasingly used as a means of transport. Because of the high registration tax (180%), <a href="/wiki/VAT" title="VAT" class="mw-redirect">VAT</a> (25%), and one of the world's highest income tax rates, new cars are very expensive. The purpose of the tax is to discourage car ownership. The car fleet has increased by 45% over the last 30 years.
In 2007 an attempt was made by the government to favour environmentally friendly cars by slightly reducing taxes on high mileage vehicles. However, this has had little effect, and in 2008 Denmark experienced an increase in the import of fuel inefficient old cars<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> primarily from Germany, as the cost for older cars—including taxes—keeps them within the budget of many Danes.
The average car age (year 2011) is 9.2 years.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cycling_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cycling in Denmark (page does not exist)">Cycling in Denmark</a> is a common form of transport, particularly for the young and for city dwellers. With a network of bicycle routes extending more than 12,000&#160;km<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> and an estimated 7,000&#160;km<sup id="cite_ref-vcta_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vcta-108">[108]</a></sup> of <a href="/wiki/Segregated_cycle_facilities" title="Segregated cycle facilities">segregated dedicated bicycle paths and lanes</a>, Denmark has a solid <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cycling_infrastructure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cycling infrastructure (page does not exist)">bicycle infrastructure</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Technology">Technology</span></h3>
<p>In the 20th century, Danes have also been innovative in several fields of the technology sector. Danish companies have been influential in the shipping industry with the design of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maersk_Triple_E_class&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maersk Triple E class (page does not exist)">the largest and most energy efficient container ships in the world</a>, and Danish engineers have contributed to the design of <a href="/wiki/MAN_Diesel" title="MAN Diesel">MAN Diesel</a> engines. In the software and electronic field, Denmark contributed to design and manufacturing of <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Mobile_Telephone" title="Nordic Mobile Telephone">Nordic Mobile Telephones</a>, and the now-defunct Danish company <a href="/w/index.php?title=DanCall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DanCall (page does not exist)">DanCall</a> was among the first to develop <a href="/wiki/GSM" title="GSM">GSM</a> mobile phones.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>Danish engineers are world-leading in providing diabetes care equipment and medication products from <a href="/wiki/Novo_Nordisk" title="Novo Nordisk">Novo Nordisk</a> and, since 2000, the Danish <a href="/wiki/Biotech" title="Biotech" class="mw-redirect">biotech</a> company <a href="/w/index.php?title=Novozymes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Novozymes (page does not exist)">Novozymes</a>, the world market leader in enzymes for first generation starch based bioethanol, has pioneered development of enzymes for converting waste to <a href="/wiki/Cellulosic_ethanol" title="Cellulosic ethanol">cellulosic ethanol</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Medicon_Valley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Medicon Valley (page does not exist)">Medicon Valley</a></i>, spanning the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Region" title="Øresund Region">Øresund Region</a> between Zealand and Sweden, is one of Europe's largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Life_science&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Life science (page does not exist)">life science</a> clusters, containing a large number of life science companies and research institutions located within a very small geographical area. Danish software engineers have taken leading roles in some of the world's important programming languages: <a href="/wiki/Anders_Hejlsberg" title="Anders Hejlsberg">Anders Hejlsberg</a>, (<a href="/wiki/Turbo_Pascal" title="Turbo Pascal">Turbo Pascal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Embarcadero_Delphi" title="Embarcadero Delphi">Delphi</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=C_Sharp_(programming_language)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C Sharp (programming language) (page does not exist)">C#</a>); <a href="/wiki/Rasmus_Lerdorf" title="Rasmus Lerdorf">Rasmus Lerdorf</a>, (<a href="/wiki/PHP" title="PHP">PHP</a>); <a href="/wiki/Bjarne_Stroustrup" title="Bjarne Stroustrup">Bjarne Stroustrup</a>, (<a href="/wiki/C%2B%2B" title="C++">C++</a>); <a href="/wiki/David_Heinemeier_Hansson" title="David Heinemeier Hansson">David Heinemeier Hansson</a>, (<a href="/wiki/Ruby_on_Rails" title="Ruby on Rails">Ruby on Rails</a>); <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lars_Bak_(computer_programmer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lars Bak (computer programmer) (page does not exist)">Lars Bak</a>, a pioneer in virtual machines (<a href="/w/index.php?title=V8_(JavaScript_engine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="V8 (JavaScript engine) (page does not exist)">V8</a>, <a href="/wiki/Java_virtual_machine" title="Java virtual machine">Java VM</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dart_(programming_language)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dart (programming language) (page does not exist)">Dart</a>); <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lene_Vestergaard_Hau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lene Vestergaard Hau (page does not exist)">Lene Vestergaard Hau</a> (physicist), the first person to stop light, leading to advances in <a href="/wiki/Quantum_computing" title="Quantum computing" class="mw-redirect">quantum computing</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nanoscale_engineering&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nanoscale engineering (page does not exist)">nanoscale engineering</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Linear_optics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Linear optics (page does not exist)">linear optics</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_policy">Public policy</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Denmark_Confirms_Participation_in_E-ELT.jpg" title="File:Denmark Confirms Participation in E-ELT.jpg">File:Denmark Confirms Participation in E-ELT.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">With an investment of 8.5 million euros over the ten-year construction period, Denmark confirms participation in <a href="/w/index.php?title=E-ELT&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="E-ELT (page does not exist)">E-ELT</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>After deregulating the labour market in the 1990s, Denmark has one of the most free labour markets in European countries. According to World Bank labour market rankings, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Labour_market_flexibility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Labour market flexibility (page does not exist)">labour market flexibility</a> is at the same levels as the United States. Around 80% of employees belong to unions and the unemployment funds that are attached to them. Labour market policies are mainly determined by negotiations between the workers' unions and employers' unions, and the government only interferes if labour strikes extend for too long.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Despite the success of the trade unions, a growing number of people make contracts individually rather than collectively, and many (four out of ten employees) are contemplating dropping especially unemployment fund but occasionally even union membership altogether. The average employee receives a benefit at 47% of their <a href="/wiki/Wage" title="Wage">wage level</a> if they have to claim benefits when unemployed. With low unemployment, very few expect to be claiming benefits at all. The only reason then to pay the earmarked money to the unemployment fund would be to retire early and receive <a href="/wiki/Retirement" title="Retirement">early retirement</a> pay (<i>efterløn</i>), which is possible from the age of 60 provided an additional earmarked contribution is paid to the unemployment fund.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">unemployment rate</a> for December 2007 was 2.7%, for a total of 74,900 persons, a reduction by 112,800 persons—2,400 per month—or 60% since December 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> unemployment number for August 2008 is 2.9%. Another measure of the situation on the labour market is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Employment_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Employment rate (page does not exist)">employment rate</a>, that is the percentage of people aged 15 to 64 in employment out of the total number of people aged 15 to 64. The employment rate for Denmark in 2007 was 77.1% according to Eurostat. Of all countries in the world, only <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> with 78.% and <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> with 85.1% had a higher employment rate. Of the employed more than 38% (800,000 people)<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> of the total workforce  work in public sector jobs.
</p><p>The number of unemployed is forecast to be 65,000 in 2015. The number of people in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legal_working_age&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legal working age (page does not exist)">working age</a> group, less disability pensioners etc., will grow by 10,000 to 2,860,000, and jobs by 70,000 to 2,790,000;<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Part-time" title="Part-time">part-time</a> jobs are included.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Because of the present high demand and short supply of skilled labour, for instance for factory and service jobs, including hospital nurses and physicians, the annual average <a href="/wiki/Working_time" title="Working time">working hours</a> have risen, especially compared with the <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">recession</a> 1987–1993.<sup id="cite_ref-BusinessDK_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BusinessDK-117">[117]</a></sup> Increasingly, service workers of all kinds are in demand, i.e. in the <a href="/wiki/Mail" title="Mail">postal services</a> and as bus drivers, and academics.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In the fall of 2007, more than 250,000 foreigners are working in the country, of which 23,000 still reside in Germany or Sweden.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> According to a sampling survey of over 14,000 enterprises from December 2007 to April 2008 39,000 jobs were not filled, a number much lower than earlier surveys, confirming a downturn in the <a href="/wiki/Business_cycle" title="Business cycle">economic cycle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>The level of <a href="/wiki/Unemployment_benefits" title="Unemployment benefits">unemployment benefits</a> is dependent on former employment (the maximum benefit is at 90% of the wage) and at times also on membership of an unemployment fund, which is almost always—but need not be—administered by a trade union, and the previous payment of contributions. However, the largest share of the financing is still carried by the central government and is financed by general taxation, and only to a minor degree from earmarked contributions. There is no taxation, however, on proceeds gained from selling one's home (provided there <i>was</i> any <a href="/w/index.php?title=Home_equity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Home equity (page does not exist)">home equity</a> (<span lang="da"><i>friværdi</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>)), as the marginal tax rate on capital income from housing savings is around 0%.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> In 2011, 13.4% of Denmark's population was reported to live below the poverty line.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> When adjusted for taxes and transfers, the poverty rate drops from 24% to 6%, one of the lowest of all <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a> nations.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Denmark follows the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nordic_model&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nordic model (page does not exist)">Nordic model</a> of a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a>, characterised by a large <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a>, a high level of public expenditure and a universal social system (including <a href="#Health_care">health care</a>), financed by taxes and not by social contributions. The welfare model is accompanied by a taxation system that is both broad based (25% VAT, not including excise, duty and tax) and with a <a href="/wiki/Progressive_tax" title="Progressive tax">progressive income tax</a> model, meaning the more money that is earned, the higher income tax percentage that gets paid (minimum tax rate for adults is 42% scaling to over 60%, except for the residents of <a href="/wiki/Ertholmene" title="Ertholmene">Ertholmene</a> that escape the otherwise ubiquitous 8% healthcare tax fraction of the income taxes<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>). Other taxes include the registration tax on private vehicles, at a rate of 180%, on top of VAT. Lately (July 2007) this has been changed slightly in an attempt to favour more <a href="/wiki/Fuel_efficiency" title="Fuel efficiency">fuel efficient</a> cars but maintaining the average taxation level more or less unchanged.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Denmark_1.January_2012_by_ancestry_and_continents_of_origin..gif" title="File:Population of Denmark 1.January 2012 by ancestry and continents of origin..gif">File:Population of Denmark 1.January 2012 by ancestry and continents of origin..gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Population by ancestry and continents of origin, 2012.</div></div></div>
<p>According to 2012 figures from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Statistics_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Statistics Denmark (page does not exist)">Statistics Denmark</a>, 89.6% of Denmark's population of over 5,580,516 is of <a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danish</a> descent (defined as having at least one parent who was born in Denmark and has Danish citizenship).<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnic_groups_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnic_groups-128">[128]</a></sup> Many of the remaining 10.4% are immigrants—or descendants of recent immigrants—from neighbouring countries, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkey</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraqi_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraqi people (page does not exist)">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somali_people" title="Somali people">Somalia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Asia (page does not exist)">South Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>. Of the 10.4%, approximately 200,000 (34%) are of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_world&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western world (page does not exist)">Western</a> background, and approx. 390,000 (66%) have a non-Western background.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Median" title="Median">median</a> age is 41.4 years, with 0.97 males per female. 99% of the population (age 15 and up) is literate. The <a href="/wiki/Fertility_rate" title="Fertility rate" class="mw-redirect">fertility rate</a> is 1.73 children born per woman (2013 est.). Despite the low birth rate, the population is still growing at an average annual rate of 0.23%.<sup id="cite_ref-factbook_48-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faroese_language" title="Faroese language">Faroese</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greenlandic_language" title="Greenlandic language">Greenlandic</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official languages</a> of mainland Denmark, the Faroes, and Greenland, respectively; German is an official minority language in the former <a href="/wiki/South_Jutland_County" title="South Jutland County">South Jutland County</a> near the German border. Danish is spoken throughout the kingdom and is the <a href="/wiki/National_language" title="National language">national language</a> of Denmark. English and German are the most widely spoken foreign languages.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>Denmark is frequently ranked as the happiest country in the world in cross-national studies of <a href="/wiki/Happiness" title="Happiness">happiness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Taylor_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taylor-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Levy_article_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levy_article-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BruceStokes_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BruceStokes-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sauter_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sauter-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Earth_Institute_2013_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Earth_Institute_2013-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Roskilde_mpazdziora.JPG" title="File:Roskilde mpazdziora.JPG">File:Roskilde mpazdziora.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Roskilde_Cathedral" title="Roskilde Cathedral">Roskilde Cathedral</a> has been the burial place of Danish royalty since the 15th century. In 1995 it became a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, 79.1%<sup id="cite_ref-church_stats_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-church_stats-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> of the population of Denmark were members of the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Denmark" title="Church of Denmark">Church of Denmark</a> (<span lang="da"><i>Den danske folkekirke</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>), the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">officially established</a> church, which is <a href="/wiki/Lutheran" title="Lutheran" class="mw-redirect">Lutheran</a> in tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> This is down 0.7% compared to the year earlier and 1.3% down compared to two years earlier. Despite the high membership figures, only 3% of the population regularly attend Sunday services.<sup id="cite_ref-report_2009_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-report_2009-134">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Denmark" title="Constitution of Denmark">Constitution</a> states that a member of the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Royal_Family" title="Danish Royal Family">Royal Family</a> must be a part of the Church of Denmark, though the rest of the population is free to adhere to other faiths.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FoR_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FoR-138">[138]</a></sup> In 1682 the state granted limited recognition to three religious groups dissenting from the Established Church: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholicism_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholicism in Denmark (page does not exist)">Roman Catholicism</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reformed_Synod_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reformed Synod of Denmark (page does not exist)">the Reformed Church</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Jews_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of the Jews in Denmark (page does not exist)">Judaism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FoR_138-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FoR-138">[138]</a></sup> although conversion to these groups from the Church of Denmark remained illegal initially.  Until the 1970s, the state formally recognised "religious societies" by <a href="/wiki/Royal_decree" title="Royal decree" class="mw-redirect">royal decree</a>. Today, religious groups do not need official government recognition in Denmark, they can be granted the right to perform weddings and other ceremonies without this recognition.<sup id="cite_ref-FoR_138-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FoR-138">[138]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam in Denmark (page does not exist)">Denmark's Muslims</a> make up approximately 3% of the population and form the country's second largest religious community and largest minority religion.<sup id="cite_ref-report_2009_134-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-report_2009-134">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-muslimpopulation_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-muslimpopulation-139">[139]</a></sup> As of 2009 there are nineteen recognised Muslim communities in Denmark.<sup id="cite_ref-muslimpopulation_139-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-muslimpopulation-139">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> As per an overview of various religions and denominations by the Danish Foreign Ministry, other religious groups comprise less than 1% of the population individually and approximately 2% when taken all together.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>A new religious group, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forn_Si%C3%B0r_%E2%80%94_%C3%81satr%C3%BA_and_Vanatr%C3%BA_Association_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forn Siðr — Ásatrú and Vanatrú Association in Denmark (page does not exist)">Forn Siðr</a>, describes itself as a revival of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norse_paganism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norse paganism (page does not exist)">Norse paganism</a> prevalent in Denmark before <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christianization_of_Scandinavia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christianization of Scandinavia (page does not exist)">Christianisation</a>. It gained state recognition in November 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a 2010 <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">Eurobarometer Poll</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> 28% of Danish citizens polled responded that they "believe there is a God", 47% responded that they "believe there is some sort of spirit or life force" and 24% responded that they "do not believe there is any sort of spirit, God or life force". Another poll, carried out in 2009, found that 25% of Danes believe Jesus is the son of God, and 18% believe he is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Redeemer_(Christianity)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Redeemer (Christianity) (page does not exist)">saviour</a> of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B8benhavns_universitet_lektionskatalog_1537.jpg" title="File:Københavns universitet lektionskatalog 1537.jpg">File:Københavns universitet lektionskatalog 1537.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The oldest surviving Danish lecture plan dated 1537 from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen" title="University of Copenhagen">University of Copenhagen</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Danish education system provides access to <a href="/wiki/Danish_Folkeskole_Education" title="Danish Folkeskole Education">primary school</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Denmark" title="Secondary education in Denmark">secondary school</a> and <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher education</a>. All college and university education in Denmark is free of charges; there are no tuition fees to enroll in courses. Students in secondary school or higher and aged 18 or above may apply for state educational support grants, known as <i>Statens Uddannelsesstøtte (SU)</i> which provides fixed financial support, disbursed monthly. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Education_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Education Index (page does not exist)">Education Index</a> lists Denmark 16th in 2011 based on mean years of schooling (of adults) and expected years of schooling (of children).<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>Primary school is known as the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Folkeskole_Education" title="Danish Folkeskole Education">folkeskole</a>. Attendance at primary school is not compulsory, but most Danish children go to primary school for 10 years, from the age of 6 to 16. Whilst attending a primary school is not compulsory, receiving education at primary school-level is and must be provided for nine years. There are no final exams, but pupils in primary schools can choose to go to a test when finishing ninth grade. The test is obligatory if further education is to be attended. Pupils can alternatively attend a private independent school (<span lang="da"><i>friskole</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>), or a private school (<span lang="da"><i>privatskole</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>) – schools that are not under the administration of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_municipalities_of_Denmark" title="List of municipalities of Denmark">municipalities</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Christian_school" title="Christian school">Christian schools</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Waldorf_education&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Waldorf education (page does not exist)">Waldorf schools</a>.
</p><p>Following graduation from primary school, there are several educational opportunities; the <a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(Denmark)" title="Gymnasium (Denmark)">Gymnasium (STX)</a> attaches importance in teaching a mix of humanities and science, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Higher_Technical_Examination_Programme_(HTX)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Higher Technical Examination Programme (HTX) (page does not exist)">Higher Technical Examination Programme (HTX)</a> focuses on scientific subjects and the <a href="/wiki/Higher_Commercial_Examination_Programme" title="Higher Commercial Examination Programme">Higher Commercial Examination Programme</a> emphasizes on subjects in economics. <a href="/wiki/Higher_Preparatory_Examination_(HF)" title="Higher Preparatory Examination (HF)">Higher Preparatory Examination (HF)</a> is similar to <i>Gymnasium (STX)</i>, but is one year shorter.
For specific professions, there is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vocational_secondary_education_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vocational secondary education in Denmark (page does not exist)">vocational education</a>, training young people for work in specific <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trade_(occupation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trade (occupation) (page does not exist)">trades</a> by a combination of teaching and <a href="/wiki/Apprenticeship" title="Apprenticeship">apprenticeship</a>.
</p><p>Danish universities and other higher education institutions offer international students a range of opportunities for obtaining an internationally recognised qualification in Denmark. Many programmes may be taught in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English language (page does not exist)">English language</a>, the academic <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor's degree">bachelor's degrees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Master%27s_degree" title="Master's degree">master's degrees</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_of_Philosophy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor of Philosophy (page does not exist)">Ph.D.s</a> and <a href="/wiki/Student_exchange_program" title="Student exchange program">student exchange programmes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">Health care</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Along with Sweden and Norway, Denmark has a <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system, financed by taxes and not by social contributions. This system is largely financed through local, municipal taxation with integrated funding and provision of <a href="/wiki/Health_care" title="Health care">health care</a> at the regional level. It is the most important area of responsibility for the local regions. Unlike the former counties, the regions are not allowed to levy taxes, and the health service is primarily financed by a national health care contribution of 8 percent (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-da (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-da</a>) combined with funds from both government and municipalities.<sup id="cite_ref-expat_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-expat-74">[74]</a></sup> Denmark spends 9.8 percent of GDP on healthcare. The life expectancy in Denmark is 78.6 years, and there is one doctor for every 294 persons in Denmark.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Denmark, like its Scandinavian neighbours, has historically been one of the most socially progressive cultures in the world. In 1969, Denmark was the first country to legalise <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pornography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pornography (page does not exist)">pornography</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> and in 2012, Denmark replaced its "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Registered_partnership_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Registered partnership in Denmark (page does not exist)">registered partnership</a>" laws, which it had been the first country to introduce in 1989,<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gender-neutral_marriage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gender-neutral marriage (page does not exist)">gender-neutral marriage</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> Modesty, punctuality but above all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Social_equality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Social equality (page does not exist)">equality</a> are important aspects of the Danish way of life.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>The astronomical discoveries of <a href="/wiki/Tycho_Brahe" title="Tycho Brahe">Tycho Brahe</a> (1546–1601), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ludwig_A._Colding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ludwig A. Colding (page does not exist)">Ludwig A. Colding</a>'s (1815–1888) neglected articulation of the principle of <a href="/wiki/Conservation_of_energy" title="Conservation of energy">conservation of energy</a>, and the brilliant contributions to atomic physics of <a href="/wiki/Niels_Bohr" title="Niels Bohr">Niels Bohr</a> (1885–1962) indicate the range of Danish scientific achievement. The fairy tales of <a href="/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen" title="Hans Christian Andersen">Hans Christian Andersen</a> (1805–1875), the philosophical essays of <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B8ren_Kierkegaard" title="Søren Kierkegaard">Søren Kierkegaard</a> (1813–1855), the short stories of <a href="/wiki/Karen_Blixen" title="Karen Blixen">Karen Blixen</a> (penname <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isak_Dinesen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isak Dinesen (page does not exist)">Isak Dinesen</a>), (1885–1962), the plays of <a href="/wiki/Ludvig_Holberg" title="Ludvig Holberg">Ludvig Holberg</a> (1684–1754), and the dense, aphoristic poetry of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Piet_Hein_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Piet Hein (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Piet Hein</a> (1905–1996), have earned international recognition, as have the symphonies of <a href="/wiki/Carl_Nielsen" title="Carl Nielsen">Carl Nielsen</a> (1865–1931). From the mid-1990s, Danish films have attracted international attention, especially those associated with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dogme_95&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dogme 95 (page does not exist)">Dogme 95</a> like those of <a href="/wiki/Lars_Von_Trier" title="Lars Von Trier" class="mw-redirect">Lars Von Trier</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_media">Popular media</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Danish cinema dates back to 1897 and since the 1980s has maintained a steady stream of product due largely to funding by the state-supported <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Film_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Film Institute (page does not exist)">Danish Film Institute</a>.  The three big internationally important waves of Danish cinema have been the erotic melodrama of the <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent era</a>, the increasingly explicit sex films of the 1960s and 1970s, and lastly, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dogme_95&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dogme 95 (page does not exist)">Dogme 95</a> movement of the late 1990s.  Danish films have been noted for their realism, religious and moral themes, sexual frankness and technical innovation. The Danish filmmaker <a href="/wiki/Carl_Theodor_Dreyer" title="Carl Theodor Dreyer">Carl Th. Dreyer</a> (1889–1968) is considered one of the greatest directors of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Early_cinema&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Early cinema (page does not exist)">early cinema</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-name_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-name-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other Danish filmmakers of note include <a href="/wiki/Erik_Balling" title="Erik Balling">Erik Balling</a>, the creator of the popular <i><a href="/wiki/Olsen_Gang" title="Olsen Gang">Olsen-banden</a></i> films; <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Axel" title="Gabriel Axel">Gabriel Axel</a>, an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award (page does not exist)">Oscar</a>-winner for <i><a href="/wiki/Babette%27s_Feast" title="Babette's Feast">Babette's Feast</a></i> in 1987; and <a href="/wiki/Bille_August" title="Bille August">Bille August</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award (page does not exist)">Oscar</a>-, <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a>- and <a href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globe</a>-winner for <i><a href="/wiki/Pelle_the_Conqueror" title="Pelle the Conqueror">Pelle the Conqueror</a></i> in 1988. In the modern era, notable filmmakers in Denmark include <a href="/wiki/Lars_von_Trier" title="Lars von Trier">Lars von Trier</a>, who co-created the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dogme_95&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dogme 95 (page does not exist)">Dogme film movement</a>, and multiple award-winners <a href="/wiki/Susanne_Bier" title="Susanne Bier">Susanne Bier</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicolas_Winding_Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicolas Winding Refn (page does not exist)">Nicolas Winding Refn</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mads_Mikkelsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mads Mikkelsen (page does not exist)">Mads Mikkelsen</a> is a world-renowned Danish actor, having starred in films such as <i><a href="/wiki/King_Arthur_(film)" title="King Arthur (film)">King Arthur</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Casino_Royale_(2006_film)" title="Casino Royale (2006 film)">Casino Royale</a></i>, the Danish film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Hunt_(2012_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Hunt (2012 film) (page does not exist)">The Hunt</a></i>, and currently in the American TV series <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hannibal_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hannibal (TV series) (page does not exist)">Hannibal</a></i>.
</p><p>Danish mass media and news programming are dominated by a few large corporations. In printed media <a href="/w/index.php?title=JP/Politikens_Hus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="JP/Politikens Hus (page does not exist)">JP/Politikens Hus</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berlingske_Media&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berlingske Media (page does not exist)">Berlingske Media</a>, between them, control the largest news papers <a href="/wiki/Politiken" title="Politiken">Politiken</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berlingske_Tidende&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berlingske Tidende (page does not exist)">Berlingske Tidende</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jyllands-Posten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jyllands-Posten (page does not exist)">Jyllands-Posten</a> and major tabloids <a href="/w/index.php?title=B.T._(tabloid)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B.T. (tabloid) (page does not exist)">B.T.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ekstra_Bladet" title="Ekstra Bladet">Ekstra Bladet</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Television_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Television in Denmark (page does not exist)">In television</a>, publicly owned stations <a href="/wiki/DR_(broadcaster)" title="DR (broadcaster)">DR</a> and <a href="/wiki/TV_2_(Denmark)" title="TV 2 (Denmark)">TV 2</a> have large shares of the viewers.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> In radio, DR has a near monopoly, currently broadcasting on all four nationally available <a href="/wiki/FM_broadcasting" title="FM broadcasting">FM</a> channels, competing only with local stations. The <a href="/wiki/Mainstream_media" title="Mainstream media">mainstream media</a> is still very much dominant in Denmark, but the share of Danes going online for news is steadily growing.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:right; float:right; margin-left:1em">

<tr>
<th align="center"><a href="/wiki/Carl_Nielsen" title="Carl Nielsen">Carl Nielsen</a><br /><small><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wind_Quintet_(Nielsen)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wind Quintet (Nielsen) (page does not exist)">Wind Quintet</a>, Op. 43<br /> 1st movement</small>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left; background:#dcdcdc;"> <a href="/wiki/File:Carl_Nielsen_-_Wind_Quintet_-_1._Allegro_ben_moderato.ogg" title="File:Carl Nielsen - Wind Quintet - 1. Allegro ben moderato.ogg">120px</a>
</td></tr></table>
<p>Copenhagen and its multiple outlying islands have a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_traditional_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish traditional music (page does not exist)">wide range of folk traditions</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Orchestra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Orchestra (page does not exist)">Royal Danish Orchestra</a> is among the world's oldest orchestras. Denmark's most famous classical composer is <a href="/wiki/Carl_Nielsen" title="Carl Nielsen">Carl Nielsen</a>, especially remembered for his six symphonies and his <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wind_Quintet_(Nielsen)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wind Quintet (Nielsen) (page does not exist)">Wind Quintet</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Danish_Ballet" title="Royal Danish Ballet">Royal Danish Ballet</a> specializes in the work of the Danish choreographer <a href="/wiki/August_Bournonville" title="August Bournonville">August Bournonville</a>. Danes have distinguished themselves as <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> musicians, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen_Jazz_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copenhagen Jazz Festival (page does not exist)">Copenhagen Jazz Festival</a> has acquired an international reputation.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Victor_Borge" title="Victor Borge">Victor Borge</a>, a Danish comedian and musician, achieved world renown in stage, radio and television appearances spanning 60 years, with his unique blend of comedy and piano playing.
</p><p>In the early days of rock and beat, Danish artists quickly adapted this new type of music with success and jazz's popularity waned. The modern <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a> and rock scene has produced a few names of note, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aqua_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aqua (band) (page does not exist)">Aqua</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Volbeat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Volbeat (page does not exist)">Volbeat</a>, <a href="/wiki/D-A-D" title="D-A-D">D-A-D</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nekromantix" title="Nekromantix">Nekromantix</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dizzy_Mizz_Lizzy" title="Dizzy Mizz Lizzy">Dizzy Mizz Lizzy</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Raveonettes" title="The Raveonettes">The Raveonettes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Learns_to_Rock" title="Michael Learns to Rock">Michael Learns to Rock</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alphabeat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alphabeat (page does not exist)">Alphabeat</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Outlandish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Outlandish (page does not exist)">Outlandish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Efterklang" title="Efterklang">Efterklang</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Medina_(singer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Medina (singer) (page does not exist)">Medina</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oh_Land&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oh Land (page does not exist)">Oh Land</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_(band)" title="Kashmir (band)">Kashmir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mew_(band)" title="Mew (band)">Mew</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=D%C3%BAn%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dúné (page does not exist)">Dúné</a>. All together, <a href="/wiki/Lars_Ulrich" title="Lars Ulrich">Lars Ulrich</a>, the drummer of the band <a href="/wiki/Metallica" title="Metallica">Metallica</a>, has become the first Danish musician to be inducted into the <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rock and Roll Hall of Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a>.
</p><p>More recently, in 2013 Denmark entered the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Eurovision Song Contest">Eurovision Song Contest</a> and won with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emmelie_de_Forest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emmelie de Forest (page does not exist)">Emmelie de Forest</a>'s song 'Only Teardrops'. The Eurovision song contest 2014 will be held in Denmark.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture_and_design">Architecture and design</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pv_jensen-klint_05_grundtvig_memorial_church_1913-1940.jpg" title="File:Pv jensen-klint 05 grundtvig memorial church 1913-1940.jpg">File:Pv jensen-klint 05 grundtvig memorial church 1913-1940.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Grundtvig%27s_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grundtvig's Church (page does not exist)">Grundtvig's Church</a> in Copenhagen. An example of expressionist architecture.</div></div></div>
<p>Denmark's architecture became firmly established in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> when first <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_style" title="Romanesque style" class="mw-redirect">Romanesque</a>, then <a href="/wiki/Gothic_style" title="Gothic style" class="mw-redirect">Gothic</a> churches and cathedrals sprang up throughout the country. From the 16th century, Dutch and Flemish designers were brought to Denmark, initially to improve the country's fortifications, but increasingly to build magnificent royal castles and palaces in the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_architecture" title="Renaissance architecture">Renaissance</a> style.
During the 17th century, many impressive buildings were built in the <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">Baroque</a> style, both in the capital and the provinces. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neoclassical_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neoclassical architecture (page does not exist)">Neoclassicism</a> from France was slowly adopted by native Danish architects who increasingly participated in defining architectural style. A productive period of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Historicism_(art)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Historicism (art) (page does not exist)">Historicism</a> ultimately merged into the 19th-century <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Romantic_style&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Romantic style (page does not exist)">National Romantic style</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 20th century brought along new architectural styles; including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Expressionist_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Expressionist architecture (page does not exist)">expressionism</a>, best exemplified by the designs of architect <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peder_Vilhelm_Jensen-Klint&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peder Vilhelm Jensen-Klint (page does not exist)">Peder Vilhelm Jensen-Klint</a>, which relied heavily on Scandinavian brick Gothic traditions; and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nordic_Classicism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nordic Classicism (page does not exist)">Nordic Classicism</a>, which enjoyed brief popularity in the early decades of the century. It was in the 1960s that Danish architects such as <a href="/wiki/Arne_Jacobsen" title="Arne Jacobsen">Arne Jacobsen</a> entered the world scene with their highly successful <a href="/wiki/Functionalism_(architecture)#Danish_Functionalism" title="Functionalism (architecture)">Functionalist architecture</a>. This, in turn, has evolved into more recent world-class masterpieces including <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B8rn_Utzon" title="Jørn Utzon">Jørn Utzon</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Opera_House" title="Sydney Opera House">Sydney Opera House</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johann_Otto_von_Spreckelsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johann Otto von Spreckelsen (page does not exist)">Johann Otto von Spreckelsen</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Grande_Arche" title="Grande Arche">Grande Arche de la Défense</a> in Paris, paving the way for a number of contemporary Danish designers such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bjarke_Ingels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bjarke Ingels (page does not exist)">Bjarke Ingels</a> to be rewarded for excellence both at home and abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Danish design is a term often used to describe a style of <a href="/wiki/Functionalism_(architecture)" title="Functionalism (architecture)">functionalistic</a> design and architecture that was developed in mid-20th century, originating in Denmark. Danish design is typically applied to industrial design, furniture and household objects, which have won many international awards.
</p><p>The Danish Porcelain Factory ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Copenhagen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Copenhagen (page does not exist)">Royal Copenhagen</a>") is famous for the quality of its ceramics and export products worldwide. Danish design is also a well-known brand, often associated with world-famous designers and architects such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=B%C3%B8rge_Mogensen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Børge Mogensen (page does not exist)">Børge Mogensen</a> (1914–1972), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Finn_Juhl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Finn Juhl (page does not exist)">Finn Juhl</a> (1912–1989), <a href="/wiki/Hans_Wegner" title="Hans Wegner">Hans Wegner</a> (1914–2007), <a href="/wiki/Arne_Jacobsen" title="Arne Jacobsen">Arne Jacobsen</a> (1902–1971), <a href="/wiki/Poul_Kj%C3%A6rholm" title="Poul Kjærholm">Poul Kjærholm</a> (1929–1980), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poul_Henningsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poul Henningsen (page does not exist)">Poul Henningsen</a> (1894–1967) and <a href="/wiki/Verner_Panton" title="Verner Panton">Verner Panton</a> (1926–1998).<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Georg_Jensen" title="Georg Jensen">Georg Jensen</a> (1866–1935) is noted for his modern design in silver.
</p><p>Other designers of note include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kristian_Solmer_Vedel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kristian Solmer Vedel (page does not exist)">Kristian Solmer Vedel</a> (1923–2003) in the area of industrial design, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jens_Harald_Quistgaard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jens Harald Quistgaard (page does not exist)">Jens Harald Quistgaard</a> (1919–2008) for kitchen furniture and implements and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ole_Wanscher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ole Wanscher (page does not exist)">Ole Wanscher</a> (1903–1985) who had a classical approach to furniture design.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Constantin_Hansen_1836_-_HC_Andersen.jpg" title="File:Constantin Hansen 1836 - HC Andersen.jpg">File:Constantin Hansen 1836 - HC Andersen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A portrait of <a href="/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen" title="Hans Christian Andersen">Hans Christian Andersen</a> (1836), by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christian_Albrecht_Jensen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christian Albrecht Jensen (page does not exist)">Christian Albrecht Jensen</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The first known Danish literature is myths and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_folklore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish folklore (page does not exist)">folklore</a> from the 10th and 11th century. <a href="/wiki/Saxo_Grammaticus" title="Saxo Grammaticus">Saxo Grammaticus</a>, normally considered the first Danish writer, worked for bishop <a href="/wiki/Absalon" title="Absalon">Absalon</a> on a chronicle of <a href="/wiki/History_of_Denmark" title="History of Denmark">Danish history</a> (<a href="/wiki/Gesta_Danorum" title="Gesta Danorum">Gesta Danorum</a>). Very little is known of other Danish literature from the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>. With the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a> came <a href="/wiki/Ludvig_Holberg" title="Ludvig Holberg">Ludvig Holberg</a> whose comedy plays are still being performed.
</p><p>In the late 19th century, literature was seen as a way to influence society. Known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Modern_Breakthrough&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Modern Breakthrough (page does not exist)">Modern Breakthrough</a>, this movement was championed by <a href="/wiki/Georg_Brandes" title="Georg Brandes">Georg Brandes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henrik_Pontoppidan" title="Henrik Pontoppidan">Henrik Pontoppidan</a> (awarded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Prize_in_Literature&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Prize in Literature (page does not exist)">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Jens_Peter_Jacobsen" title="Jens Peter Jacobsen">J.&#160;P. Jacobsen</a>. <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a> influenced the renowned writer and poet <a href="/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen" title="Hans Christian Andersen">Hans Christian Andersen</a>, known for his stories and <a href="/wiki/Fairy_tale" title="Fairy tale">fairy tales</a>, e.g. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ugly_Duckling" title="The Ugly Duckling">The Ugly Duckling</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid" title="The Little Mermaid">The Little Mermaid</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Snow_Queen" title="The Snow Queen">The Snow Queen</a></i>. In recent history <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Vilhelm_Jensen" title="Johannes Vilhelm Jensen">Johannes Vilhelm Jensen</a> was also awarded the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_for_Literature" title="Nobel Prize for Literature" class="mw-redirect">Nobel Prize for Literature</a>. <a href="/wiki/Karen_Blixen" title="Karen Blixen">Karen Blixen</a> is famous for her novels and <a href="/wiki/Short_story" title="Short story">short stories</a>. Other Danish writers of importance are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gustav_Wied&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gustav Wied (page does not exist)">Gustav Wied</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Heinesen" title="William Heinesen">William Heinesen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martin_Andersen_Nex%C3%B8" title="Martin Andersen Nexø">Martin Andersen Nexø</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Piet_Hein_(Denmark)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Piet Hein (Denmark) (page does not exist)">Piet Hein</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hans_Scherfig&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hans Scherfig (page does not exist)">Hans Scherfig</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Klaus_Rifbjerg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Klaus Rifbjerg (page does not exist)">Klaus Rifbjerg</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dan_Tur%C3%A8ll&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dan Turèll (page does not exist)">Dan Turéll</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tove_Ditlevsen" title="Tove Ditlevsen">Tove Ditlevsen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Inger_Christensen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Inger Christensen (page does not exist)">Inger Christensen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peter_H%C3%B8eg" title="Peter Høeg">Peter Høeg</a>.
</p><p>Danish philosophy has a long tradition as part of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_philosophy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western philosophy (page does not exist)">Western philosophy</a>. Perhaps the most influential Danish philosopher was <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B8ren_Kierkegaard" title="Søren Kierkegaard">Søren Kierkegaard</a>, the creator of <a href="/wiki/Christian_existentialism" title="Christian existentialism">Christian existentialism</a>. Kierkegaard had a few Danish followers, including <a href="/wiki/Harald_Hoffding" title="Harald Hoffding" class="mw-redirect">Harald Høffding</a>, who later in his life moved on to join the movement of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Positivism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Positivism (page does not exist)">positivism</a>. Among Kierkegaard's other followers include <a href="/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre" title="Jean-Paul Sartre">Jean-Paul Sartre</a> who was impressed with Kierkegaard's views on the individual, and <a href="/wiki/Rollo_May" title="Rollo May">Rollo May</a>, who helped create <a href="/wiki/Humanistic_psychology" title="Humanistic psychology">humanistic psychology</a>. Another Danish philosopher of note is <a href="/wiki/N._F._S._Grundtvig" title="N. F. S. Grundtvig">Grundtvig</a>, whose philosophy gave rise to a new form of non-aggressive nationalism in Denmark, and who is also influential for his theological and historical works.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Painting_and_photography">Painting and photography</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:C_W_Eckersberg_1841_-_Kvinde_foran_et_spejl.jpg" title="File:C W Eckersberg 1841 - Kvinde foran et spejl.jpg">File:C W Eckersberg 1841 - Kvinde foran et spejl.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Woman in front of a Mirror</i>, (1841), by <a href="/wiki/Christoffer_Wilhelm_Eckersberg" title="Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg">Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg</a></div></div></div>
<p>While Danish art was influenced over the centuries by trends in Germany and the Netherlands, the 15th- and 16th-century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Church_frescos_in_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Church frescos in Denmark (page does not exist)">church frescos</a>, which can be seen in many of the country's older churches, are of particular interest as they were painted in a style typical of native Danish painters.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
