</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danish_Golden_Age&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danish Golden Age (page does not exist)">Danish Golden Age</a>, which began in the first half of the 19th century, was inspired by a new feeling of nationalism and romanticism. <a href="/wiki/Christoffer_Wilhelm_Eckersberg" title="Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg">Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg</a> was not only a productive artist in his own right but taught at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Danish_Academy_of_Fine_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts (page does not exist)">Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts</a> where his students included notable painters such as <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Bendz" title="Wilhelm Bendz">Wilhelm Bendz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christen_K%C3%B8bke" title="Christen Købke">Christen Købke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martinus_R%C3%B8rbye" title="Martinus Rørbye">Martinus Rørbye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Constantin_Hansen" title="Constantin Hansen">Constantin Hansen</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_Marstrand" title="Wilhelm Marstrand">Wilhelm Marstrand</a>. The sculpture of <a href="/wiki/Bertel_Thorvaldsen" title="Bertel Thorvaldsen">Bertel Thorvaldsen</a> was also significant during this period.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1871, <a href="/wiki/Holger_Drachmann" title="Holger Drachmann">Holger Drachmann</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Karl_Madsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Karl Madsen (page does not exist)">Karl Madsen</a> visited <a href="/wiki/Skagen" title="Skagen">Skagen</a> in the far north of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jutland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jutland (page does not exist)">Jutland</a> where they quickly built up one of Scandinavia's most successful <a href="/w/index.php?title=Skagen_Painters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skagen Painters (page does not exist)">artists' colonies</a> specializing in <a href="/wiki/Naturalism_(arts)" title="Naturalism (arts)" class="mw-redirect">Naturalism</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Realism_(arts)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Realism (arts) (page does not exist)">Realism</a> rather than in the traditional approach favoured by the Academy. Hosted by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Ancher" title="Michael Ancher">Michael</a> and his wife <a href="/wiki/Anna_Ancher" title="Anna Ancher">Anna</a>, they were soon joined by <a href="/w/index.php?title=P.S._Kr%C3%B8yer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="P.S. Krøyer (page does not exist)">P.S. Krøyer</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Locher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carl Locher (page does not exist)">Carl Locher</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Laurits_Tuxen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Laurits Tuxen (page does not exist)">Laurits Tuxen</a>. All participated in painting the natural surroundings and local people.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> Similar trends developed on Funen with the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fynboerne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fynboerne (page does not exist)">Fynboerne</a></i> who included <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johannes_Larsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johannes Larsen (page does not exist)">Johannes Larsen</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fritz_Syberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fritz Syberg (page does not exist)">Fritz Syberg</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Hansen_(painter)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Hansen (painter) (page does not exist)">Peter Hansen</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Funish_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Funish-163">[163]</a></sup> and on the island of Bornholm with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bornholm_school_of_painters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bornholm school of painters (page does not exist)">Bornholm school of painters</a> including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Niels_Lergaard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Niels Lergaard (page does not exist)">Niels Lergaard</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kr%C3%A6sten_Iversen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kræsten Iversen (page does not exist)">Kræsten Iversen</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oluf_H%C3%B8st&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oluf Høst (page does not exist)">Oluf Høst</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>Danish photography has developed from strong participation and interest in the very beginnings of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_photography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of photography (page does not exist)">art</a> in 1839 to the success of a considerable number of <a href="/wiki/Danes" title="Danes">Danes</a> in the world of <a href="/wiki/Photography" title="Photography">photography</a> today. Pioneers such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mads_Alstrup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mads Alstrup (page does not exist)">Mads Alstrup</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Georg_Emil_Hansen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Georg Emil Hansen (page does not exist)">Georg Emil Hansen</a> paved the way for a rapidly growing profession during the last half of the 19th century while both artistic and press photographers made internationally recognised contributions. Today Danish photographers such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Astrid_Kruse_Jensen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Astrid Kruse Jensen (page does not exist)">Astrid Kruse Jensen</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jacob_Aue_Sobol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jacob Aue Sobol (page does not exist)">Jacob Aue Sobol</a> are active both at home and abroad, participating in key exhibitions around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>Collections of modern art enjoy unusually attractive settings at the <a href="/wiki/Louisiana_Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Louisiana Museum of Modern Art">Louisiana Museum of Modern Art</a> north of <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a> and at the North Jutland Art Museum in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aalborg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aalborg (page does not exist)">Aalborg</a>. Notable artists include the <a href="/wiki/Neo-expressionism" title="Neo-expressionism">Neo-Expressionist</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Per_Kirkeby&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Per Kirkeby (page does not exist)">Per Kirkeby</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tal_R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tal R (page does not exist)">Tal R</a> with his wild and colorful paintings,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Olafur_Eliasson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olafur Eliasson (page does not exist)">Olafur Eliasson</a>'s space exhibitions<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jeppe_Hein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jeppe Hein (page does not exist)">Jeppe Hein</a>'s installations.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sm%C3%B8rrebr%C3%B8d-01.jpg" title="File:Smørrebrød-01.jpg">File:Smørrebrød-01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Smørrebrød</i> – a variety of Danish open sandwiches piled high with delicacies.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Cuisine" title="Cuisine">cuisine</a> of Denmark, like that of the other Nordic countries and of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Germany (page does not exist)">Northern Germany</a>, consists mainly of meat and fish. This stems from the country's agricultural past, its geography, and its climate of long, cold winters. With <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of meat per person consumed in 2002, Denmark has the highest consumption of meat per person of any country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>The open sandwiches, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Sm%C3%B8rrebr%C3%B8d" title="Smørrebrød">smørrebrød</a></i>, which in their basic form are the usual fare for lunch, can be considered a national speciality when prepared and decorated with a variety of fine ingredients. Hot meals traditionally consist of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ground_meat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ground meat (page does not exist)">ground meats</a>, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Frikadeller" title="Frikadeller">frikadeller</a></i> (meat balls), or of more substantial meat and fish dishes such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fl%C3%A6skesteg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flæskesteg (page does not exist)">flæskesteg</a></i> (roast pork with crackling) or <i>kogt torsk</i> (poached cod) with mustard sauce and trimmings. Denmark is known for its <a href="/wiki/Carlsberg_Group" title="Carlsberg Group">Carlsberg</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tuborg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tuborg (page does not exist)">Tuborg</a> beers and for its <a href="/wiki/Akvavit" title="Akvavit">akvavit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bitters" title="Bitters">bitters</a> although imported wine is now gaining popularity.
</p><p>Danish chefs, inspired by continental practices, have in recent years developed an innovative series of <a href="/wiki/Gourmet" title="Gourmet">gourmet</a> dishes based on high-quality local produce. As a result, Copenhagen and the provinces now have a considerable number of highly acclaimed restaurants of which several have been awarded <a href="/wiki/Michelin_Guide" title="Michelin Guide">Michelin stars</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:US_Open_2009_4th_round_156.jpg" title="File:US Open 2009 4th round 156.jpg">File:US Open 2009 4th round 156.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Caroline_Wozniacki" title="Caroline Wozniacki">Caroline Wozniacki</a>, professional women's tennis player and former <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_players&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of WTA number 1 ranked players (page does not exist)">world no. 1</a> on the <a href="/wiki/WTA_Tour" title="WTA Tour" class="mw-redirect">WTA Tour</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Sports are popular in Denmark, and its citizens participate in and watch a wide variety. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_sport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National sport (page does not exist)">national sport</a> is <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>. Denmark  qualified six times in a row between 1984 and 2004 for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UEFA_European_Football_Championship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UEFA European Football Championship (page does not exist)">European Championships</a>, and won the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1992_UEFA_European_Football_Championship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1992 UEFA European Football Championship (page does not exist)">Championship in 1992</a>. Other significant achievements include winning the Confederations Cup in 1995 and reaching the quarter-final of the 1998 World Championships. Notable Danish footballers include <a href="/wiki/Peter_Schmeichel" title="Peter Schmeichel">Peter Schmeichel</a>, named the "World's Best Goalkeeper" in 1992 and 1993, and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Laudrup" title="Michael Laudrup">Michael Laudrup</a>, named the best Danish player of all time by the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Football_Association" title="Danish Football Association">Danish Football Association</a> in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is much focus on handball, too. The women's national team celebrated great successes during the 1990s, while in the last decade, the men's team have been more successful. Denmark has qualified for numerous semifinals and finals at the European and World Championships and is often on top of the official world rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, Denmark's best tennis and golf players have had some remarkable results. <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Wozniacki" title="Caroline Wozniacki">Caroline Wozniacki</a> has been world number one in women's tennis, and in 2012, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frederik_L%C3%B8chte_Nielsen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frederik Løchte Nielsen (page does not exist)">Frederik Løchte Nielsen</a> surprisingly won the Wimbledon doubles tournament together with a British player. In golf, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Bj%C3%B8rn" title="Thomas Bjørn">Thomas Bjørn</a> has twice finished as a runner-up at British Open, and counts as one of Europe's best players since the mid-1990s. Other strong players are Anders Hansen, Søren Hansen, Søren Kjeldsen, and Thorbjørn Olesen.
</p><p>Denmark has had a strong tradition within the sport of cycling, too. However, the successes of riders such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rolf_S%C3%B8rensen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rolf Sørensen (page does not exist)">Rolf Sørensen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bjarne_Riis" title="Bjarne Riis">Bjarne Riis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Rasmussen" title="Michael Rasmussen">Michael Rasmussen</a> have shown to have been based on the use of <a href="/wiki/Doping" title="Doping">doping</a>.
</p><p>In motorsports, Denmark has primarily excelled in <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle_speedway" title="Motorcycle speedway">speedway racing</a>, winning several world championships since the 1970s. <a href="/wiki/Tom_Kristensen" title="Tom Kristensen">Tom Kristensen</a> then put car racing on top of the Danish sports agenda, as he took his first trophy at the 24 hour race in Le Mans in 1997. He has now (2014) been a member of the winning team nine times, an all-time record.
</p><p>Boxing has also been a focus in Denmark. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mikkel_Kessler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mikkel Kessler (page does not exist)">Mikkel Kessler</a>, "The Viking Warrior", has become a staple icon in boxing circles. Kessler is a five-time world champion, having held the WBA title two additional times and the WBC super middleweight championship twice as well.
</p><p>Other popular sports in Denmark include sailing and rowing (Denmark specialize in light-weight rowing and are particularly known for their light-weight coxless four, having won six gold and two silver World Championship medals and three gold and two bronze Olympic medals). Denmark's numerous beaches and resorts are popular locations for fishing, canoeing, kayaking, windsurfing, and many other water-themed sports. Many female Danish swimmers have had great results in recent years, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rikke_M%C3%B8ller_Pedersen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rikke Møller Pedersen (page does not exist)">Rikke Møller Pedersen</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jeanette_Ottesen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jeanette Ottesen (page does not exist)">Jeanette Ottesen</a>.
</p><p>Indoors, sports such as <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Table_tennis" title="Table tennis">table tennis</a> and gymnastics attract many Danes, too. An interest which is reflected in great results at international competitions. However, when asking the average Dane about active hobbies, he or she is most likely to mention running or fitness as preferred activities.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<p>{{#invoke:Portal|portal}}
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Index_of_Denmark-related_articles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Index of Denmark-related articles (page does not exist)">Index of Denmark-related articles</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Outline_of_Denmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Outline of Denmark (page does not exist)">Outline of Denmark</a>
</li>

		</div>
